resources.string: "Goodbye."
"Through that portal is vengeance, nothing more."
"It's all right. I'm going with you."
"We all have devils on our back, Aribeth."
<StartAction>[Leave.]</Start>
[PC KNOWS TRUE NAME]<StartAction>[Command Aribeth by her True Name]</Start> "Va'ardalia the Twinsouled..."
"Nothing. Never mind..."
"Feel no guilt regarding what transpired in Neverwinter."
"Surrender your soul to me!"
"If it means losing you, then no."
"Yes, I am sure."
[VFX. ARIBETH TURNS TO ICE. PLAYER GETS SOME ENHANCEMENT. EVIL ALIGNMENT HIT]
"I command you to pursue good, not evil." [VFX, CHANGE HER SWORD VFX, CHANGE HER ALIGNMENT, CHANGE PC'S ALIGNMENT]
[MALE, ROMANCE < 2] "I command you to love me!" [SET ROMANCE TO 2]
"That is all, Aribeth."
"What does it matter?"
"Do you want me to?"
"What are you about to do?"
"Then no, Aribeth. I never did..."
"Then yes, against my better judgment, I'm afraid I do." [SET ROMANCE TO 2]
"Then yes, with all the blackness of my heart..." [SET ROMANCE TO 2]
[SHE IS PC'S TRUE LOVE] "Then yes, you are my one true love." [SET ROMANCE TO 2]
"No, Aribeth. I never did..."
"Well, we've had our fun but I wouldn't call it love..."
"Against my better judgment, I'm afraid I do." [SET ROMANCE TO 2]
"Yes, with all the blackness of my heart..." [SET ROMANCE TO 2]
[SHE IS PC'S TRUE LOVE] "You are my one true love." [SET ROMANCE TO 2]
"Come, gentle spirit. Let us finish what we started.
"Rest here awhile. I will travel without you."
"Come, fell spirit. Let us finish what we started."
"Do what you will. I have no further use for you."
"Goodbye."
"I understand you challenged Mephistopheles."
"How did Mephistopheles respond?"
"Why is whether or not you loved him so important?"
"Once you've embraced evil, there's no turning back."
"Fine. Tyr chose you as his paladin, then. Do you doubt his wisdom?"
"Then pursue it now with all the blackness of your heart!"
"You're in hell. It's a bit late to doubt your true nature."
"You were very good at being evil, Aribeth."
"Don't you wish to be powerful? To have your vengeance?"
"Tyr chose you as his paladin. Do you doubt his wisdom?"
"Fine. Once you've embraced evil, there's no turning back."
"You acted out of a sense of justice."
"Let Tyr decide if he will take you."
"You did not act alone."
"Then be righteous, here in the depths of hell."
"Then it is Tyr's mistake, not yours."
"If not for love, why did you do it?"
"Mephistopheles wants you to feel that way."
"You were to marry. How could you not love him?"
"Mephistopheles is just toying with your emotions."
"I live by my own laws as well."
"But what of morality, of good and evil?"
"I think I know you from somewhere."
"Why do you try to forget them?"
"I won't let that happen."
"Fine, what do I care?"
"I understand."
"You don't want that."
"Why did you attack me?"
"I thought I knew you from somewhere."
"I had questions I wanted to ask you."
"I believed you were making a mistake."
"I wanted to torture you."
"I needed your help."
"I felt sorry for you."
"You were cold so I warmed you."
"I seek the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man."
"Back to my other questions."
"Do you know the answer or don't you?"
"Please, m'Lady, you must help."
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> "Then tell me the answer."
"How have the gods spited you?"
"Who was this man you loved?"
Leave.

Demonic Grappling Hand

This hand seems to have a life about it. It wriggles and writhes as you hold it, constantly gripping at your fingers.
When properly thrown, it will latch onto nearby obstacles - provided there is something it can grab onto. Upon hooking onto something, it will pull its owner over to it, and place itself back in its owner's backpack.
The Demonic Grappling Hand can also be used to manipulate some objects, like activating them, or pulling them closer to its owner.
Gruul's Bracer
Dream Journal, Vol. I

The Sleeping Man dreams more and more about his search, now, tossing and turning restlessly as I probe deeper into his thoughts. The search had led him to the vast wastes of Cania, well beyond the Gates. I could almost feel the biting cold he suffered, on the verge of death amidst the blinding snows. He had a ring that turned the whole world dark and marked the path that compelled him ever forward. Every step was agony but every step brought him closer to his quest's completion. Only at the end of the dream did the nature of that quest become clear. He sought the Knower of Places... Thus I learned the Fourth-Fold Mystery of the Sleeping Man. He has slept more peacefully ever since and he has not dreamed of his time in the wastes since.
Sensei's Amulet

Sensei Dharvana uses this amulet to focus on the dreams of the Sleeping Man. For those of sufficient mental acuity, simply wearing the amulet while in the Sleeping Man's presence should be sufficient to bring any latent psionic powers to the fore.
Trumpet of Pandemonium
Bent and battered, this strange trumpet is somehow linked to the howling winds of Pandemonium. Its sound is definitely more jarring than it is musical.

Velox Potion

The potion contained within this bottle can warm the body for quite some time. The energy of the Velox Berries it was made from, has been harnessed within.
When times are tough, and there are no berries or wood to be found, this potion can be a life-saver.
Velox Berry

This highly sought after berry has a very unique attribute at its core. While it is not edible for most beings, it does provide a fiery spark when crushed or broken apart.
This can be quite useful for anyone travelling in harsh environments, as the spark can be used on flammable objects to create a fire that can burn far longer and far warmer than natural fires.
Band of Fire and Frost

Engraved on the face of this ring are two symbols - one to represent fire and one to represent ice. When these forces work together in harmony, the body is at peace with either of these elements.
It seemingly did its last owner no good, but this balancing power in the hands of either of the ring's elemental ties could cause a great uprising.
It is for this reason that the previous owner must have "hid" it away and embraced his death rather than giving it up.

Sponge Spores

Sponge Spores are small, living bits of fungus, broken off of Water Mold. When eaten, the Spores die and release their air into the bloodstream of the imbiber.
This release of air only lasts a short while, but during that time, breathing is unnecessary, making travel through harsh, gaseous areas and deep waterways possible.
Water Mold

Water Mold is a very rare fungus, found only in remote caverns and swamps.
The Water Mold itself is not very useful, but the hundreds of living Sponge Spores it contains are.
When broken off, the Sponge Spores immediately replace themselves, feeding off the very air we breathe.
These Spores contain pockets of air, and when eaten can be very useful in the right situation.
Use this item to break off some Sponge Spores.

Shroud of Kings
This is a very ordinary looking cloak.

The origin of this cloak dates back to the days when King Richard Garrison held power in Cania. It was crafted for him by his servant, a demented and twisted man named Pony Tall.
Pony was not a gifted being, but he managed to sew the cloak in a matter of just a few days. Barely resembling a cloak, Pony Tall had done the best he could and so wrapped the tattered garment up and made way to his master.
After giving the cloak to the King, Pony was slaughtered for his foul gift, his blood staining and possibly corrupting the garment.
Before tossing the cloak out along with Pony's body, King Richard put it on to mock his dead, incompetant servant. Upon doing so, he felt better - in all ways - and the cold night air ceased.
It was never known how the cloak came to have the powers it has, but most suspect they actually originated from his dead servant's blood.

Hammer of The Glacier

The dwarven smith Silverblade forged the first of these hammers - purportedly combining a masterfully crafted warhammer with a Girdle of Giant Strength and Gauntlets of Ogre Power - as a gift for his military-bound son. Sadly, the son fell before the hammer's completion and, in grief, Silverblade took it up himself, dying in valiant battle. Recently, the dwarf Barun reassembled the device, leading to the creation of additional variants by other master smiths.
This is one of those variants.

The smells of hickory smoke and fresh bread waft out of the earthen oven, making your mouth water.

A Howl in the Night

You have stumbled upon a pack of winter wolves deep in the wastes of Cania. They seem skittish and frightened but not overtly hostile. They must have a den somewhere nearby and an alpha wolf who leads them.

The leader of a pack of winter wolves has warned you of a clan of frost giants who live nearby, deep in Cania's frozen wastes. Some of the wolf pups have been stolen and the pack would no doubt be happy to see their young safely returned.
You have freed a group of wolf pups being held captive by a nearby giant clan. The pups yipped excitedly as they raced off for the safety of their den. The pack will be relieved by their safe return.
A group of wolf pups lie slaughtered outside a giant fortress, their blood pooling in the trodden snow. You wondered if their pack will survive this endless winter without them.

You have killed the leader of a wolf pack deep in the frozen wastes of Cania. Though he was no match for you in the end, he fought with the fury of a cornered animal. Without his strength and guidance, you doubt the remainder of the pack will survive the endless winter.
A Lost Leader

In speaking with the Spirits of the Dead who cluster around the Gates of Cania, you have learned that they had a leader who had stood up to Mephistopheles when he first announced that he would be devouring their souls to fuel his undead army on the Prime Material plane. He must have done something dire to her, however, for after the confrontation, she fled to a cave in the center of the city where she now refuses to speak with anyone. The Spirits say she's becoming one of the Lost, those who have given up hope and are slowly merging with the icy essence of Cania.

You have found the cave in which the so-called Lost Leader of the Spirits of the Dead has sequestered herself. The cave rests atop a ridge in the city's heart and though she has sealed the entrance with some form of spell, you were able to hear her sobs echoing from deep within. A strange dog-like creature paced back and forth, whining outside the cave's entrance.

You were able to guide the strange dog-like creature you found outside the Lost Leader's cave to where it needed to be. Once led to the right location, it shot a beam of energy into the city's icy walls, carving the Spirit Leader's name into the ice so she could finally become one of the lost. Leaning closer, you were able to read the newly carved name: "Aribeth de Tylmarande." Curious, you wonder if the magical barrier she had placed at the cave entrance has faded with her passing.

There, in an ice-sheathed cavern at the heart of the City of Lost Souls, you beheld Aribeth de Tylmarande, the Lost Leader of the Spirits of the Dead. A thick layer of frost clings to her once-lithe frame, her ghostly shape at last made solid by the ice of Cania. Half-burned logs rest in a blackened pit before her, their flames long since quenched by the cavern's icy chill.

In an effort to thaw the frozen statue of Aribeth de Tylmarande, the Lost Leader of the Spirits of the Dead, you have expended a single precious velox berry to create a fire. Unfortunately, the paltry flames did little to combat the cavern's icy chill and were soon extinguished.

In an effort to thaw the frozen statue of Aribeth de Tylmarande, the Lost Leader of the Spirits of the Dead, you have expended two precious velox berries to create a fire. While the flames were sufficient to warm the confined space of the cavern, they were not enough to penetrate the icy chill that still clings to Aribeth's ghostly form.

Thanks to your efforts, Aribeth de Tylmarande, the Lost Leader of the Spirits of the Dead was rescued from the bitter chill of Cania. To your surprise, she expressed her gratitude by drawing her ghostly blade and pressing you to the attack.

Lost and now found, hostile and now pacified, Aribeth de Tylmarande, the ghostly leader of the Spirits of the Dead has surrendered herself to your will. It seems she has given up on life, even the threadbare shred experienced by the Spirits of the Dead. For your efforts to rescue her from the icy grasp of Cania to go unwasted, you will have to speak with her and convince her that she has something worth living for.

You have rescued Aribeth de Tylmarande, the ghostly leader of the Spirits of the Dead, from the icy grip of Cania. Thanks to your efforts and persistence, she has dedicated what remains of this threadbare afterlife to the cause of good. With that, you have restored her to her former paladinhood and she has offered to aid you in your quest through hell.

You have rescued Aribeth de Tylmarande, the ghostly leader of the Spirits of the Dead, from the icy grip of Cania. Thanks to your efforts and persistence, she has dedicated what remains of this threadbare afterlife to the cause of evil. With that, you have restored her to her former status as a fearsome Blackguard and she has offered to aid you in your quest through hell.
Arden Swift

Trapped here much like you, a group of Githzerai Pilgrims have related an interesting tale regarding a certain fellow named Arden Swift who has been traveling with them for the past while. According to the prevailing gossip, Arden got into an argument with the Pilgrims' leader regarding his sacriligious plans to wake the so-called Sleeping Man who the Pilgrims are here to visit. Arden's currently drowning his sorrows in the Hellbreath Tavern in the city's southeast corner.

You have met a jester, Arden Swift, in the Hellbreath Tavern in the city's southeast corner. He seems somehow associated with the Githzerai Pilgrims currently patronizing the establishment but, given his tiefling heritage and the dirty looks they occasionally slip him over their half-empty tankards, you're unsure how.

In talking with Arden Swift, a bard traveling with the Githzerai, he has told you of his rather sacriligious plans to wake their so-called Sleeping Man using a Trumpet of Pandemonium he acquired somewhere in his travels. Due to a quick intervention on the part of the Pilgrims' Sensei, the jester's plan never came to pass but he still carries the trumpet and it might be possible to convince him to part with it.

Arden Swift, patron of the Hellbreath Tavern and itinerant jester currently taveling with the entourage of Githzerai Pilgrims, has placed his beloved Trumpet of Pandemonium as a prize for an upcoming card game. He had intended to used the trumpet to wake the so-called Sleeping Man but had been caught red-handed by the Pilgrims' Sensei before he could sound its blast. If you're interested in acquiring it for yourself, you merely have to place your ante on the table and guess the card he's holding in five questions or less. You're not entirely sure if you can trust him but it might be worth a try.

With some quick thinking and a good eye, you were able to win Arden Swift's Trumpet of Pandemonium in a game of cards. Although he cheated regularly throughout the actual game, he was good on his word and handed over the trumpet as soon as you won. You suspect he was more interested in the antes you put in, as he's probably racked up a hefty tab with the rather evil-looking bartender.

In a visit to the Hellbreath Tavern, you managed to pickpocket a trumpet from the jester Arden Swift. It looks dented and old. Though its sound quality probably leaves something to be desired, you're pretty sure it's going to be loud.

In a visit to the Hellbreath Tavern, you managed to pick a fight with the jester Arden Swift. Rummaging through his pack when it was all done, you found a strange-looking trumpet, dented and old. Though its sound quality probably leaves something to be desired, you're pretty sure it's going to be loud.
Using the Trumpet of Pandemonium you acquired from Arden Swift, you were able to do the unthinkable: wake the Sleeping Man...
Crystals in the Ice

Peering into an ice crystal that that thrust itself up from Cania's glacial floor, you saw a vision of Mephistopheles' progress in the Prime Material Plane. It appears that he has discovered the carnage left behind by the Seer's defeat. As he passed through the rotting carcasses, they rose in his wake, a ghostly army bound to do his bidding...

Peering into an ice crystal that that thrust itself up from Cania's glacial floor, you saw a vision of Mephistopheles' progress in the Prime Material Plane. It appears that, together with his newly created army, he is slowly winding his way to the surface, sowing destruction in his wake. Mephistopheles seems to feed off the ruin he is causing. With every moment, he grows stronger...

Peering into an ice crystal that that thrust itself up from Cania's glacial floor, you saw a vision of Mephistopheles' progress in the Prime Material Plane. It appears that he has made his way to the surface, emerging in the Yawning Portal. Many of the patrons were incinerated by his deadly gaze, though you don't yet know the fate of Durnan and his family. Even so, time grows short and the city of Waterdeep is in great peril.
Escape from the Hells

The familiar blackness of death enveloped you but the blood-red eyes of your betrayer, Mephistopheles, lingered to the end. And then you woke to find your eyes reflected in the Gatekeeper's shimmering skin. Everything seems strangely familiar...

The archdevil Mephistopheles has played you for a fool. He has commanded your mysterious ally, the Gatekeeper, to bar your return to Waterdeep on the Prime Material plane, trapping you instead in some hellish world called Cania. The Gatekeeper seems sympathetic to your plight but claims he has no choice but to obey for Mephistopheles has commanded him by his True Name. Such names seem to have a strange power in this place and it seems the only way to break Mephistopheles' prohibition will be learn the Gatekeeper's True Name for yourself.

Your search for the Gatekeeper's True Name has turned up its first clue: one of the citizens of this strange city claims that an old and venerable creature known as the Sleeping Man might have the information your looking for. He sleeps in the city's northwest quarter and apparently has done so for longer than anyone can remember. Hopefully, with his help, you'll be able to return home to Waterdeep and take your vengeance on the archdevil Mephistopheles.

The Sleeping Man was not as helpful in your quest for the Gatekeeper's True Name as you had hoped. You did learn, however, of an ancient race called the Knowers that populated Cania before it was colonized by the legions of hell. One of them, the Knower of Names, was banished by Mephistopheles to an unknown prison deep in Cania's frozen wastelands. Unable to find the Knower of Names, the Sleeping Man instead sought out her sister, the Knower of Places, with the help of a magical ring that that served as his guide through Cania's wastes. If you can repeat his feat, perhaps she will be able to help you find her sister's hidden prison. The Sleeping Man broke the ring into three parts and hid it in a guarded room below his chambers. It seems your journey will begin there.

The Sleeping Man's ring that will lead you to the Knower of Places and hopefully to the Gatekeeper's True Name is a strange artifact indeed. When you slip it onto your finger, it is as if you can see into another sort of space, another dimension. Some things are present there that are not present in the real world and some things you would expect to find have disappeared. One thing you are grateful to see, however, are a line of glowing arrows that will hopefully chart a safe course through Cania's vast wastelands. You feel the stirrings of hope in your chest for the first time since Mephistopheles banished you to this frozen place.

Tormented by her loneliness, the Knower of Places has agreed to help you on your quest for the Gatekeeper's True Name. She has woven a new magic into the Sleeping Man's ring, allowing it to guide you to her sister, the Knower of Names, just as it guided you to her. She left you with a cryptic parting message that will hopefully aid you when you reach her sister's icy prison: "You are not the first to seek the prison and not the first to find it. At 7 o'clock a hole was dug and a fearsome devil freed. If he'd have come but sixteen hours prior, he'd have uncovered what you need." Hopefully you'll be able to compel the Gatekeeper to return you to Waterdeep before Mephistopheles has destroyed your home forever.

At long last you have learned the True Name of the Gatekeeper: Hecugoth the Abandoned. You say it aloud a few times, rolling it around on your tongue. It has sad sound to it but you are eager to put it to use. It's your ticket out of here, back to Waterdeep and the Prime Material or whatever still remains of them after the chaos that Mephistopheles has sown in your absence. The Relic of the Reaper will take you back to the Gates of Cania but you pause to consider whether you have any pressing tasks you wish to accomplish on this plane before you go. Facing Mephistopheles won't be easy and you'd better have made your peace with the world.

Commanded by his True Name, the Gatekeeper has opened a Planar Gate that will lead you back home to Waterdeep. Mephistopheles won't be expecting you so you'll have to take advantage of whatever element of surprise you have. It will pay to be well-prepared before you step through that gate.

Waterdeep is in shambles and your sudden appearance has brought scant hope to Durnan and the handful of citizens and soldiers still trying to resist Mephistopheles' forces. It's clear they're fighting a war of movement, winning what battles they can and surrendering ground whenever Mephistopheles himself makes an appearance. Though you dared not say it in their presence, you doubt their ragtag resistance will survive much longer without your assistance. This time, when Durnan retreats from Mephistopheles' advance, you intend to be waiting for him.

Amidst the chaos of battle and shattered streets, Durnan and his brave but dwindling army retreated from Mephistopheles' approach. The arch-devil towers over the city's architecture, reducing it to rubble with a gaze. There, in the scattered remnants of the proudest city of the Prime Material, you prepare to make your stand against the devil's onslaught...

And with that, Mephistopheles is defeated. Dark clouds linger in the graying sky above, the sounds of battle slowly growing still in the distance. Weary yet triumphant, you stop to ponder the significance of your victory...

She listed the Five-Fold Mysteries as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?

Your reward is a crystalline amulet that she says will help you focus your thoughts on the dreams of the Sleeping Man, provided you have any latent psionic powers. The door into the temple's Inner Sanctum is now unlocked to you.

Defiling the holy confines of the Temple of the Sleeping Man, you have assassinated its leader, the Sensei Dharvana. Looting through her bloodied corpse, you found an interesting crystalline amulet about her neck. You pocket it surreptitiously, eager to explore the remainder of the temple.

There, in the temple's Inner Sanctum, with the winged form of the Sleeping Man prostrate before you, you tried in vain to make use of the Sensei's amulet. The crystal glowed a murky green when in his presence and you could feel its growing hum but you somehow lacked the wisdom to tap into its psionic powers.

There, in the temple's Inner Sanctum, with the winged form of the Sleeping Man prostrate before you, you made use of the Sensei's amulet. The crystal glowed a murky green when in his presence and you could feel its growing hum and then, all at once, you found yourself swept up within his dreams.

There, in the temple's dim green light, the Sensei's amulet clasped about your neck, you dreamed the dreams of the Sleeping Man. Mephistopheles was there and a woman called the Knower of Names, whom he banished. And an older woman, the Knower of Places, whom the Sleeping Man had visited in search of his one true love. Throughout his quest, he was somehow guided by a ring that now lies, buried and guarded, in a chamber below him. If you hope to find the Knowers, you will need that ring upon your finger...
There, in the temple's dim green light, you have done the unthinkable and woken the Sleeping Man. Hopefully he will be able to tell you the Gatekeeper's True Name.

In waking the Sleeping Man, you unleashed the Sensei's fury. Driven mad with rage, she attacked and you had no choice but to defend yourself. Now she lies dead at the feet of the Sleeping Man who she worshiped. About her neck is a crystalline amulet. You snap it off, casually pocketing it as you have so many other treasures taken from the bodies of the dead.

The Sleeping Man knows many things but, sadly, the Gatekeeper's True Name is not one of them. Even so, he tells of a race of creatures called the Knowers who once called Cania home. One of them, the Knower of Names was banished by Mephistopheles long ago while the other, the Knower of Places, lives in hiding deep in Cania's frozen wastelands. His own quest had brought him the latter's hidden lair, long ago, a feat made possible only with the aid of an enchanted ring. The ring lies in a chamber under the temple, guarded and kept safe all these many years. He has invited you to make use of the ring, provided you can claim it, and wishes you well on your journey.

Judging by what the Mimic had been capable of, you surmise that you should be able to use it to pull yourself to certain objects or pull them to you. You have a sneaking suspicion that you'll be able to find other less conventional uses for it as well. Regardless, it appears that you simply need to be facing in the general direction of the object you intend to interact with when the grappling hand is activated.
The Prisoner

A magical platform glows high above you, a human form dimly visible upon it. It almost appears that the platform was intended as some form of prison, forever separating the mysterious figure from the world below. Perhaps there is a way to lower the platform and investigate further.

Your efforts to lower the magical prison have met with mixed success. While it didn't actually lower, per se, you were able to dissolve it. Unfortunately for the prisoner it held aloft, the results of your interference were rather catastrophic. If he wasn't already dead before the platform dissolved, he is now. Still, as the prisoner hit the ground, you heard a small ringing sound echo off the stone walls, suggesting that something else must have fallen with him.

Mould grows on the dessicated entrails of the fallen prisoner, suggesting that he was indeed dead long before your interventions. His remains are cloaked in the tangled remnants of a motheaten robe, its arcane lettering having long since faded beneath the dust. There, gleaming amidst his shriveled intestines, a golden ring pokes through the tatters of a tiny bag. It seems that the prisoner had valued it enough to swallow it and thereby hide it from his unknown captors.

It seems to want you to lead it somewhere but you're having trouble determining where it wants to go. It keeps projecting the following sequence of images to you: A sturdy oak, full with leaves, then a boy held in his father's arms. This second image seems to be focused on the boy rather than the father.

It seems you have found a friend in a small dog-like creature called the Scrivener. It speaks in the form of word pictures that it projects psionically into the air just above its head. "Be careful what you say here. There is a tension in Lith My'athar between the followers of the Seer and the drow of House Maeviir."
"Be on your guard. We are venturing into the true depths of the Underdark now."
"The darkness here is often filled with unseen dangers. Watch the shadows carefully."
"The Valsharess has many allies, but at the first sign of weakness they will turn on her. This is the way of the Underdark."
"Those who live on Toril's surface fear the drow, but far worse things than my people exist down here."
"The Underdark has no seasons; no cycle of night and day. I find the constant darkness... comforting."
"In the Underdark, you are either hunter or prey. Often you become the latter when you least expect it."
"An imposing fortress, to say the least. I doubt whoever's inside will be happy to see us."
"There is something foul in this place; it smells of ancient evil."
"I see the drow are not the only ones who like to throw their slaves into the pits to do battle."
"Can you feel it? A presence, thrumming against the walls of the skull. Guard your thoughts carefully."
"The Eye Tyrant must be close... and I doubt she will be unguarded."
"The stench of smoke and ash in this place is enough to make one gag!"
"Be careful of this woman. I suspect she is more than she appears."
"No doubt many traps and monsters lay ahead... typical for any wizard's tower."
"A jester without an audience... does nothing in this town make sense?"
"The town is gone! Imagine the power necessary to make a whole town disappear!"
"There are duergar nearby. The thick stink of their sweat fills the air."
"These golems are unlike any constructs I have seen before!"
"Be careful. Wizards who seek to prolong their life often turn themselves into powerful undead."
"The chill here is enough to freeze your very soul."
"You can feel the heat of the fire, even from here. Let's move closer and warm ourselves."
"I didn't expect it to be so warm in here."
"Look there - a woman, frozen in ice. No, wait... I think she's an elf."
"A jester in the Hells? Well, I suppose if anyone needs to be amused it's the souls trapped here."
"A mimic... but it doesn't seem to be attacking. It only seems interested in devouring gems."
"I don't see a bridge. We'll have to find some other way to cross this river of fire."
"A door made of... lightning?This looks like a trap - or a test. These levers must be the key."
"The Valsharess won't stop until she has conquered every land on the face of Toril."
"The Seer believes you will save us all from the Valsharess. I pray she is right."
"The Valsharess will send her assassins after us, but I know all their tricks."
"The creatures of the Underdark can strike without warning... as can I."
"The Seer has seen the future if we fail. The Valsharess will crush all of Toril beneath her boot heel."
"We drow are unwelcome on Toril's surface. The Seer told me that even the followers of Eilistraee face persecution and prejudice."
"Blood is easily wiped from a dagger's edge, but it is not so easily washed from your hands."
"I rarely used poison on my victims; I preferred the quick cut of a blade or the blast of my magic. It seemed more clean, more pure."
"I was taught to keep my blades sharp and a spell always at the ready. Old habits die hard."
"A wise mage knows that *when* a spell is cast is almost as important as *which* spell is cast. Preparation is often the key to battle."
"As an assassin, I was trained to kill. Those skills should serve us well in this place."
"The Seer says the surface of Toril is beautiful. One day I hope to see it for myself."
"Keep a sharp eye and a sharp blade. That was my motto when I was an assassin, and it serves us well enough now."
"Eilistraee is the goddess of moonlight. One day I hope to visit the surface of Toril and see the moon for myself."
"Sarn; walk carefully. Footsteps echo here, they can alert others to our presence."
"Vith usstan! My backpack is a mess! My spell components are all mixed up. *sigh* I'll have to sort them out next time we stop."
"Hold a second. I see something I can use as a component in one of my spells... there. We can continue now."
"If you want me to cast one of my spells before a battle, just let me know."
"I was taught one must conquer to survive; kill or be killed. That lesson holds true for us now."
"*sigh* I fear there is much killing still ahead, and my heart is already stained with the blood of a thousand murders."
"I killed my first victim when I was only a girl; a male slave who displeased me. I never even knew his name. I wonder why I'm thinking of him now?"
"I always looked into the eyes of my victims as they died. Now those eyes are burned into my mind, and I can't stop thinking about them."
"An assassin needs to be invisible, even in plain sight. It was a lesson I mastered quickly... thanks in part to my magic."
"Move with care. The element of surprise can win a battle; we must be careful not to give ourselves away."
"Everywhere I look I see places we could be ambushed. We are vulnerable here, we must be prepared for anything."
"Part of me feels I belong here; a doomed soul condemned to this Hell."
"I feel pity for those trapped here. Neither alive nor dead, with no real hope of escape."
"The Valsharess is defeated, but now we have unleashed an even greater evil on Toril."
"Mephistopheles played us for fools! We have to find a way to stop him. We have to!"
"As bad as the drow may be, the surface of Toril will fare much worse under the rule of a devil!"
<DEATH SCREAM AS HER SOUL IS RIPPED APART>
"You're going to want to speak to the Seer. Trust me, she can explain everything."
"So now you know everything... the Valsharess, who we are, why we're here, all of it. What we're doing here is very important."
"Is there something else you need from me, <FirstName>?"
"Of course, Seer." Nathyrra bows her head in acceptance, then steps forward and begins to speak.
"The drow have ever been ruled by the Matron Mothers who head the great houses. The Valsharess was once one of these: ruthless and powerful in her art, but no more so than any other Matron Mother."
"But then Lolth, the Queen of Spiders and goddess of the drow, disappeared... and drow society was thrown into utter chaos. The Valsharess seized on this opportunity."
"Once the Underdark is hers, she will turn her attention once more to the surface. She believes herself a Queen... a Valsharess, by our tongue... and her ambition knows no end."
"The priestesses of Lolth are powerless before her, and the great drow houses have bent knee, just as many of the other Underdark races have been intimidated into joining her cause."
"You stopped her plans in Undermountain for now, but she'll find another way. It won't be long. At best, you've bought us some breathing time."
"Not long ago, the devil she had enslaved warned the Valsharess that there was one who could defeat her. She ordered an augury and was presented with an image of you."
"I... didn't trust you. I still do not. For all the fact that the Seer has foreseen your coming, that does not mean that we know anything about you. I had to be cautious."
"Plus I had no idea Halaster would place a geas on you or send us down here. My goal was to stop the Valsharess in Undermountain first, and all other considerations came afterward."

"This isn't the time or the place... my love." It's obvious she is all but choking on the word.
"Mephistopheles will destroy all of Waterdeep if we do not stop him. There is no time for conversation."
"I suppose we can spare a few moments away from our quest to speak. What do you want to talk about?"
"I just wanted you to know that I'm starting to understand why the Valsharess is afraid of you... and why the Seer has so much faith in you."
"When all this is over, what do you plan to do next? I mean... you will go back to the surface, won't you?"
Nathyrra gives you a soft smile. "Now you're just teasing me. Please, this is serious."
The drow seems momentarily taken aback by your offer, then quickly recovers. "You are joking, of course. But my question was a serious one."
"I have never been to the surface of Toril, though I have heard the Seer and some of the others speak of it. Tell me... what is it like?"
"Yes, I imagine you are eager to break the geas that has bound you to our cause. But after that, you won't have any reason to remain down here. No doubt you will go back to the surface."
"This may seem strange, considering where we are. But I don't know if we'll ever get out of here, and I want you to know something in case... well, just in case."
"Yes, out with it. That's probably the best way."
"We haven't known each other very long. But we've been through a lot together and I feel very... I feel very close to you."
She gives you an exasperated look. "Please, I'm trying to be serious."
She casts a dubious glance at the inhospitable terrain around you. "This isn't really what I'd call romantic. Please, just listen. I'm trying to explain how I feel about you."
"I've known many males in my life, but none of them ever meant anything to me. I've always looked down on them as slaves or servants. I suppose that's to be expected, considering drow society."
"But you've changed all that. You're different. When I see you, I see an equal. Someone I respect. Someone I... someone I..."
She gasps at the word, then laughs lightly at her own reaction. "Yes. That's the word. Love. I love you."
"I... I still want to serve Eilistraee, of course. But I want to do it with you by my side. I don't know how it will work out, but I'm sure it will. That is, if you feel the same way about me."
"I'm... I'm glad. Part of me was afraid that you might not share my feelings. But to know that you love me too..." she trails off, a satisfied smile on her face.
"I don't know. I suppose we should try and find a way out of this ice-bound realm. I know it will all work out, somehow. I have faith in you, my love. Wherever you lead, I will follow."
"You're right, of course. But I'm confident it will all work out, somehow. I have faith in you, my love. Wherever you lead, I will follow."
Nathyrra recoils as if she's been slapped, her eyes open wide in shock, then quickly recovers. "I... I see. Well, forgive me, then. I thought there was something more between us."
"I see now it was wrong. Don't worry, I won't bring this up again. Let's... let's just move on."
"I don't like this place. It is empty and bleak and cold. So very, very cold."
"Now that we are about to leave this wretched plane behind us forever, I am not so sure I was ever meant to return to our own world."

She suddenly rubs her arms as if cold, sighing heavily. "This is a plane of lost souls; maybe I belong here. I feel like I am caught between my past and my future, trapped without a purpose or direction."
"Eilistraee has shown me the path I must walk, but I cannot do so without looking back at every step and seeing what I have left behind."
She gives you a sad smile. "I know you will, my love. But I'm not sure there's much you can do. Though I may lean on you for support, it is I who must bear the burden of my past life."

"Let caution rule your step, here. Even the most innocent-looking creature can be filled with poison strong enough to bring down a rothe beast."
"I've always considered the Underdark to be not unlike the Abyss. In intent, anyhow."
"There is an exit to the surface not far from here that I know of. We could... search for it, if you wished."
"Don't get lost down here. Finding your bearings once you are lost in the shadows is far from simple."
"What manner of being would build such a fortress, I wonder? And better yet, how sound are their defenses?"
"Can you not feel it? We are near the Master of this terrible place. Be wary."

"Hmmm. How do we get across this river of lava? Somehow I don't think swimming is the answer."

"Where are we going? I would prefer to lead, rather than running after you all the day long."
"My armor is tarnished beyond belief. Is that rust?! I shall have to polish it the next time we stop."
"I do not like being underground. Even in the Abyss I never had the sense of such a... weight being directly overhead."
"The darkness here is interminable. It is more than shadows... it engulfs the heart and swallows courage."
"I understand the drow were once a surface race, driven underground by their surface cousins. How must they have felt, exiled to an unwelcoming land of shadowy caverns?"
"One eye to lift and one eye to sleep, One to charm man and one for beast. One eye to wound and one eye to slow, One to bring fear and one to make stone... hmmm, now I forget the rest..."
"Are you sure you are going the right way? Have we not been here before?"
"All the old legends of the greatest adventures do not mention the fact that most of it was spent walking, do they?"

"I remember when we fought against the great pit fiend, Arauchor. He used his power to open a chasm to separate us from him, then laughed that he would never be defeated... right before he slipped and fell in."
"I must admit, killing mortals is much easier that killing demons. If you remove a demon's head, all you end up with is something that tries to bite your ankles."
"I don't like how this place feels. It is as if we are being watched."
"I look forward to repaying that archdevil well for his 'kindness' in sending us here."
"Ah, yes, the hellish planes. The lands of suffering, how well I know it."
"It seems a bit... convenient... that the relic you found so long ago was part of Mephistopheles. Mind you, I suppose that's how you became involved in all of this, isn't it?"
"Ahhh, I can feel my demonic blood rebelling against my presence here. It is the Blood Wars calling me now."
"It has been some time since a lord of the Hells has been free in your world. This should be interesting... in a horrid, terrifying, 'get me out of here' kind of way, I mean."
He rubs his chin thoughtfully, seemingly unsure how to continue. "We might meet our end at any time now, and there is something I would like to get off my chest first."
He stiffens, his eyes blazing with brief anger before he looks at you. "No, there is nothing 'sappy' about it at all, though obviously I should get this over with before you insult me even more."
He nods. "You are correct. I should just get this over with."
"We have not known each other for long. I wanted you to know, however, that in the brief time we've spent together I've... come to feel quite close to you."
"I... I think I've come to know you quite well. I believe we have a companionship, perhaps even something more than that. Do you... not feel the same?"
He smiles shyly, looking away for a moment. When his eyes return to you, they are bright and filled with emotion. "I am most glad to hear it, my lady."
"My life," he begins slowly, "has been one of nothing but rage and despair. Even after I came to the Seer, I still believed that gaining my humanity was the most I could aspire to."
"I do not feel that way anymore. I believe there is something greater I could aspire to." His eyes stare into yours intensely. "I... I love you, my lady. With all my heart."
Afterwards, Valen smiles bashfully. "It is more than I could have hoped for that you might return my feelings, my lady. Nothing could make me happier."
He looks off into the distance, grinning. "I do not know, truly. All I know is that you are the most amazing woman I have ever encountered. Any future we have is enough for me."
"I know." He looks down, smiling contentedly. "I have no doubt at all that we'll make it through this. And then... well, I suppose we can talk about that then."
He nods, smiling gently even though wounded pride still shines from behind his eyes. "Of course, my lady. I... expected no more."
"Perhaps once this is over, we can speak of this again." He pauses, letting the question hang in the air as he turns away. "I... am sorry if I have made you uncomfortable, my lady. I had to say it."
"Let us move on. There is much to do if we ever wish to escape from this frozen wasteland."
Your answer was unexpected and Valen clearly looks both disappointed and uncomfortable. "Ah," he sighs. "I suppose I should have expected that."
"There is nothing wrong with counting you as a friend. I would be more than pleased to count you as one." He smiles at you shyly. "That is, of course, if you can forgive my lapse in etiquette."
He nods slowly, comprehending. "I see," he says with a great deal of embarrassment in his voice. "I am doubly the fool, then."
A pained expression crosses Valen's face and he looks away from you. "I... I see." A flush suddenly rises in his cheeks. "I suppose I should have known better than this."
"I thought... well, it doesn't matter what I thought. I was very foolish. I won't trouble you again with my thoughts, I apologize." He clears his throat abruptly. "Let's just... move on."
He chuckles uneasily. "I am serious, my lady. I wish to speak with you a moment, just you and I."
I... really, my lady! This is not what I meant at all! I just... I just wanted to tell you how I felt about you!
"I wanted to express my admiration to you. I know that you were forced by Halaster to aid us, but I think you have done far more than was required. I am grateful."
He smiles broadly. "Good. I'm glad." He motions ahead. "Let's keep going, then, friend. We have a plane yet to conquer and then an archdevil to face. Victory no longer seems quite so far away."
"Speak to the Seer. She will explain everything."
The tiefling looks you over, sizing you up. "The Seer believes you are our prophetical savior; our only hope of defeating the Valsharess. I, however, do not believe in prophecies."
"Still, you are obviously capable in your own right. And we need all the help we can get if we are to win this war. So I'm willing to take a chance."
Valen gives you a curt nod as a way of greeting. "How can I assist you?"

"Of course, the same spell that protects me also binds me here. I cannot leave this place. What was once an enchantment to protect is now twisted into an inescapable trap."
"If you each recover some of the pieces we will decide who shall be given the mirror once you both return here to me. As wise as I now am, I should be able to come up with a fair solution."
"Of course I am. You are both in competition for the same thing. I have to use that to my advantage." He gives you a sly smile. "I'd be a fool not to."
"A single shard is useless to me, <FirstName>. As part of the curse, I can only accept all five of the missing pieces at once if I am to repair the mirror. I told the same thing to Sabal."
"There are five pieces missing from the mirror, but the curse hides their location from me. Still, I understand how the magic works, and I know where they are most likely to be."
"The buildings here probably each have one: the temple, the library and the wizard's tower. I also believe Queen Shaori has one, and I would guess the merchant has the last."
"The merchant was a greedy, but very shrewd, businessman. He was by far the wealthiest of all the Avariel, which is why I believe one of the shards would end up in his possession."
"But since the curse he has abandoned his shop and given away most of his inventory. I can only hope he still has the mirror shard, or at least knows where it is."
"Queen Shaori was a kind and devoted monarch; she cared more for her people and her kingdom than she did for her own well being. Of course, all that has changed."
"She has been transformed into a reclusive hermit who cares nothing for the plight of her people. She now lives in a cave to the south-east of town, past the library."
"The tower is located on the north end of town, and was once the dwelling of the mage Petyr. But although he has left the tower, it is still a place of dangerous traps and creatures."
"The library is to the east of town. Before all this, the librarian herself was said to be the most beautiful Avariel in the entire kingdom. She lived there with her devoted husband."
"Except for the palace, the library was hardest hit by the curse. Now it is blocked from my all-seeing vision. I shudder to think what horrors have been unleashed on that place."
"The librarian and her husband were once good people, but I fear some terrible transformation may have fallen upon them. The curse of the mirror can be a truly terrible thing."
"Located on the west edge of town, it was once a shrine to Aerdrie Faenya, goddess of air and birds. The priest, Lomylithrar, was a man devoted to healing others and easing their pain."
"Now he has become a sadistic follower of Talona, mistress of poison and pestilence. He is very dangerous and completely evil: be careful in all your dealings with him."
"Surely you know who I'm talking about, <FirstName>. The drow who ambushed you when you first came here were led by Sabal, one of the Red Sisters who serves the Valsharess."
"She wants to bring the mirror to her mistress, to use it against the Seer. I have made her the same offer I am making you. If she brings me the missing pieces, I will give her the mirror."
"I care only for the Avariel trapped down here. The agent of our salvation is irrelevant to me. Once the mirror is repaired we will be transported far away from this place."
Nathyrra nods. "I've run into Sabal before. I should have recognized her sooner."
"We will settle this with battle, <FirstName>! The Red Sisters will taste your blood!"
The fool holds up a hand to quell Sabal's attack. "The spell of immunity in this room will make killing each other impossible. Though if you are both set on battle I can lift its effects.
Sabal snarls at you. "You're nothing but a coward. There is only one way you'll ever get any of the mirror shards from me: over my dead body!"
The fool sighs. "It seems a battle is inevitable. But before I lift the spell of protection from you both, there is something you should know."
"The pillars in this room have powerful magical properties you can use against your enemy. You can use the shards you have recovered to unlock these properties."
"Whichever one of you has more pieces of the mirror will be able to use more of the pillars to aid you during the battle."
"I'm sorry, but in life we rarely get to pick the time and place of our confrontations. The battle begins now."
"Wait!" Sabal interjects. "I need more time! I need reinforcements. We have to prepare."
"Hey, Boss. Drow lady is scared of you, now. Maybe she knows we going to kick her butt!"
"You don't seem quite so eager for battle now, drow. Did you finally realize you are overmatched?"
"What's the matter, Sabal? Are you just realizing now that you're in over your head?"
"Nobody talks to Boss like that! Not when Deekin is around!"
"I've heard about you, kobold. A walking joke, they say. But I don't find you amusing enough to let you live!"
"Think about your move carefully, drow. It may be the last one you make!"
"You don't scare me, tiefling! You will bleed just as easily as <FirstName>!"
"Make the first move, Sabal. You won't be the first Red Sister to fall beneath my blade!"
"When I deliver the mirror to my mistress I will be sure to tell her of your death, Nathyrra. She will take extra pleasure in knowing you are no more!"
"Why must you explain anything to this fool? Let me kill <him/her> and this will all be over!"
"Quiet, Sabal. <FullName> has as much right to know what is going on as you."
"My name is Elicid. I used to be a simple-minded man who danced to amuse Queen Shaori. But I have become all-knowing and all-wise ever since we were pulled through the mirror."
"When our city was up in the Lost Peaks, Queen Shaori possessed a magical mirror. With it she could keep watch on those with great power, she could see what they were doing and planning."
"Shaori used the mirror to keep our kingdom safe, to make sure nobody could ever move against us without our knowledge. She never realized the dangers the mirror possessed."
"Shaori made the mistake of using the mirror to spy on the archmage Halaster. Halaster sensed her spell of scrying, and he attacked with powerful counter-magic."
"He turned the mirror against us. Our city - the castle, the temple, the library - was wrenched through the mirror, ripped from our mountain perch and cast down here into the darkness."
"Everybody pulled through the mirror was twisted into an opposite of their true self. The Queen abandoned her throne, the fool became all-knowing. The mirror itself shattered, trapping us here."
"Between you and Sabal you have now collected all the missing pieces of the mirror from the town. With them, I can finally break the curse that has trapped the town here."
"And as a reward for helping me, I will give the mirror to either you or Sabal... though which one of you will get the mirror has yet to be decided."
He shakes his head. "But such concerns are not mine. Once I restore the mirror, I will again be nothing more than a dancing fool."

He sighs. "What I want doesn't matter. Things must be put right. Order must be restored, even if that means I will once again be a fool." Though his voice is steady, there is a hint of fear in his eyes.
"Now that the shards have all been collected here in the throne room, I can begin the incantation to repair the mirror. Thank you, <FullName>. The Avariel are forever in debt to you."
"A noble sacrifice. I hope it is not forgotten by the others once the kingdom is restored."
"You are brave, little man. I hope your sacrifice is not forgotten when the kingdom is restored."
"I don't have time for this."
"Forget it. I'm out of here."
"How do you know about the Valsharess?"
"Time to die, clown!"
"I think I know what's going on in this town."
"Who are you? How do you know my name?"
"Go on."
"I don't get it. How did you become all-knowing?"
"Mirror? What mirror?"
"If you have a point, just get to it."
"What does this have to do with me?"
"Is there anything I can do to help?"
"So what happens if the mirror is fixed?"
"Why don't you just give the frame to me?"
"So basically, she was spying on people."
"Danger? What kind of danger?"
"I'll be back after I have all five pieces of the mirror."
"I'm not going to help you with this."
"I want to ask you some questions."
"If the mirror gets fixed, won't you go back to being a fool?"
"How come there are no driders in here?"
"What if Sabal has some of the pieces and I have the others?"
"Sounds like you're playing Sabal and I against each other."
"I have a mirror shard here for you."
"Where can I find the mirror pieces?"
"I'll be going now."
"I want to ask you something else."
"Tell me more about the merchant."
"Tell me more about Queen Shaori."
"Tell me more about the wizard's tower."
"Tell me more about the library."
"Tell me more about the temple."
"Sabal? What do you mean?"
"You'd work with drow?"
"I'm always up for killing!"
"Isn't there some other way to settle this?"
"Wait, I'm not ready for this battle yet."
"Good! Let's get this fight started."
"Forget it - I just want to kill that drow beside you!"
"Yes - what's going on here?"
"Go on."
"I don't get it. How did you become all-knowing?"
"Mirror? What mirror?"
"If you have a point, just get to it."
"What does this have to do with me?"
"Is there anything I can do to help?"
"So how does this drow figure in all this?"
"So basically, she was spying on people."

But beneath the vacant expression you half-sense something else. In his eyes you see a faint glimmer of understanding, and a yearning for what was lost but not entirely forgotten.

The wizard gives you a friendly nod. "Welcome back. It's good to see you again, we don't get many visitors here. Is there anything I can do for you?"
The wizard sighs and shakes his head sadly. "I was afraid this would happen. I tried to warn him how dangerous magic is, but he wouldn't listen."
"Good, good. Better you should have it than him. You be careful with it, though. Magic is just too dangerous to be toying around with. Is there anything else you need?"
This winged elf wears the clothing of a wizard, though what a wizard would be doing simply standing in the street is anyone's guess. He gives you a warm smile and a welcoming wave.
"Hello, there. We don't get too many visitors over here by the tower. Allow me to introduce myself: I am Petyr Trenkhold, the renowned archmage. Or should I say, former archmage."
"Oh, yes. Of course. You have things to do, I'm sure. Well, off you go then."
The former wizard man backs off, though he has some parting words. "You have a fiery temper, my <race> friend. You should learn to control it, or it may one day destroy you."
"Yes, of course. I may have turned my back on the arcane arts, but that doesn't mean I've forgotten everything I learned during my studies."
"I once dwelt within this very tower, before I realized the errors of my ways and abandoned all my magical research. And I can tell you from personal experience it is a very dangerous place."
"Like any wizard's home, my tower is filled with a variety of nefarious traps and deadly monsters; fairly standard stuff. But there is one thing that makes my tower somewhat unusual."

"I cast powerful enchantments throughout the tower that can twist magic itself, making it react in strange ways. Be warned, my friend: spells cast inside the tower could have very unexpected results."
"And of course my apprentice is still in there somewhere, seeking out the secrets that are best left undiscovered. He has chosen to continue the work that I left behind."
The ex-wizard sighs. "He used to be such a good boy. Obedient, respectful of others. I must confess, I never appreciated him for what he was. But now he's changed."
"When I gave up the magician's life, he embraced it. Strange lights and colored smoke pour out of the tower from time to time, so I know he's trying bizarre and dangerous experiments."
"I can't understand what happened to him. He just became obsessed with magic. Maybe it has something to do with that broken piece of the magic mirror I gave him."
"I would assume so. He hasn't come out of the tower since I found that piece of glass on the street and gave it to him. But I doubt he'll give it up. Not willingly, anyway."
"But please, if you go into the tower after him be careful. For both your sakes. I don't want anyone to get hurt. My apprentice is a good boy, he really is. He's just not himself lately."
"He's dead, you said so yourself. What more can I tell you?" The wizard sighs. "He was such a good boy. Never should have gotten mixed up with magic."
"But you should know all this, seeing as how you've been inside already."
"Ah, yes, the mirror shard. Shortly after we arrived here in the Underdark - and I promise, I know nothing about how that happened - I found a single piece of glass out here in the street."

"I could see it had magical properties, but I've given up the arcane so I have little use for such trinkets. I gave the mirror shard to my apprentice. He's become quite interested in such things recently."
"The only shard I knew about was the one my apprentice had inside the tower. I wasn't really interested in any others, seeing as how I've given up on magic. Sorry."
"Pleased to meet you, <FullName>. I'm not sure what you're doing here, but if you're thinking of going into this tower behind me I'd strongly advise against it."
"I used to be obsessed with the power of magic. I burned with the desire to master the arcane arts, nothing else mattered to me. I abandoned my fellow Avariel and locked myself away in this tower."
"But when our town was moved from the Lost Peaks into these underground caverns - something I had nothing to do with, I assure you - I had a revelation."
"What use is the most powerful spell if you are locked away for years to perfect it? I'd rather be a simple man with friends and a life than a powerful wizard in self-imposed exile."
"Unfortunately, my apprentice didn't see things my way. He decided to devote himself to the life I left behind, and he locked himself away in the tower."
He shrugs. "I suppose I was just ready for a change. Now I get fresh air, I get to meet people, and I'm not locked away with all my potions and tomes and scrolls."
Petyr gets a concerned expression on his face. "It does seem rather strange, though. I spent years devoted to my research. But now... it just doesn't seem that important for some reason."
"Your apprentice is dead."
"Your apprentice gave me the shard from the magic mirror."
"Goodbye."
"Out of my way, old man!"
"Can I ask you some questions?"

"I am the Valsharess, as you must already know. And you... you have proven a most frustrating adversary, worthy of my attention."

She steps toward you, her eyes suddenly traveling the length of your body as she mischievously grins. "You have proven yourself to me, <CUSTOM5002>. A powerful <male/female> able to shake all the Underdark before <him/her>."

"Together, our power would be unstoppable. With you at my side, all of the Underdark would be ours... and the surface world, as well." Her eyes meet yours, bright with eager ambition. "What do you say to that, <CUSTOM5002>?"
"Indeed?" Her grin warms. "It is good to know that you can be reasonable. I see it pointless to do battle when I need only be... flexible."

She leans in close, and you can smell an exotic, dusky perfume. "We have much that we could teach each other, <CUSTOM5002>. There are many reasons for us to join forces, and the rewards... are limitless."
The Valsharess stares at you coldly. "So you have made your decision. You are a fool, surfacer."
"Die, then, with the rebels! I shall see you on your knees before me... and then you shall truly know what it is to suffer!"
"Then you need but do one thing. When my forces attack Lith My'athar, open the gates for them. That will prove your intentions."
She smiles wickedly. "I can provide well for you, <CUSTOM5002>. If you wish, I can send you a robe of great power now... and later all you desire, and more."
"You have chosen wisely, surfacer. You need continue your charade with the rebels for only a short while before my army arrives at Lith My'athar. Do not give yourself away."
"Now I will remove this foolish geas Halaster placed you under. After that is done, you need only remember: the gates must be opened."
"You will not regret your decision. Ensure that I do not regret mine."
"I shall remove the geas I see that you are under now. After that you need only remember: the gates must be opened when my army arrives."
"Then allow me to fill you with power. I can increase your abilities, for a time. And then when we are together, you will have all the power you wish. Better?"
Slight irritation crosses her face. "So be it. But decide, and quickly."
Her smile widens. "This I can remove from you. Worry not."

She steps away from you, her expression shifting to one of brutal coldness. "Then join me because it is the intelligent thing to do. Do you truly think you can succeed with only these pathetic rebels to aid you?"
"You believe they hold you in high regard? They find you useful. When you are done, they will be done with you. You are smarter than that, <CUSTOM5002>, are you not?"
She chuckles under her breath. "You say that now, <CUSTOM5002>, but are we truly so different? Is there nothing about my offer that you might find tempting?"
Her grin warms. "Not at all. Do you think I would struggle against the inevitable, <CUSTOM5002>? Why, when we might have so much in common?"
She laughs heartily. "I see that an alliance with you would be most... stimulating, <CUSTOM5002>. You wish to be on top... as do I. I respect that."
She smiles, shrugging slightly. "As you desire. I wished only to put a name to a face that I have become quite familiar with. It is good that we finally meet, you and I."
"<CUSTOM5002>? It means only '<male/female>' in your tongue, nothing more. I would prefer to call you by your name, if you are willing to give it."
She smiles, pleased. "As you wish. I am Sinvyl, Matron Mother of House Barrit'tar and Valsharess of the Ilythiiri."
She makes a disappointed moue. "Is it to be all business, then? I have come all this way just to have us meet. This is not meant to be an unpleasant occasion."
She makes a disappointed moue. "There is no need for such hostility, <CUSTOM5002>. This is not meant to be an unpleasant occasion, this meeting of ours."
"<FullName>? So be it. A name to put to a face that I have become familiar with. I am pleased we finally meet."
The drow smirks and arches an eyebrow at you. "Indeed? I will take that as a compliment rather than an indication of complete ignorance, <CUSTOM5002>."
She chuckles, a low and sinister sound. "You are either a fool without sense, <CUSTOM5002>, or a generous flatterer. I am no goddess... yet."
"Indeed. You are no fool. You also have proven to be a most frustrating adversary, <CUSTOM5002>, and worthy of my attention."
"This? This is but an illusion projected to you, surfacer, so we may meet in safety. There is no need to be alarmed, even if you know who I am."

Nathyrra's eyes follow you, calculating. She merely nods and watches you go.

"I do not think the Valsharess commands many of these beholders, though many are not needed. Each of them carries the ability to fire magical rays from its eyestalks which have varying effects."

"I doubt we have anything to offer. The mere fact that the Eye Tyrant ruling them has chosen to ally herself with the Valsharess means she believes our enemy to be far stronger than we are."
"Carefully. If you can place some kind of magical resistance on yourself, that will offer protection against their eye-rays, which they will use against you first, trying to keep a distance."
"The rays are not their only weapon, however. Some beholders are accomplished wizards... and as a last resort, their bite can also be quite deadly."
"The average beholder has no special armor or protection against magic and weapons, however. What kills most will also kill them."
"There is nothing more for us to fear from the Eye Tyrant or her followers, thanks to you. We do not need to discuss them."
"The creatures you call mind flayers are a race of telepaths, capable of reading thoughts and controlling minds. They are known for keeping a horde of dominated thralls as servants and guards."
"These creatures are ruled over by entities known as Overminds. The Valsharess has many illithid in her army, so it is likely she has recruited the aid of several Overminds."

"To the west of here is Zorvak'Mur, a small illithid colony. If we can find the Zorvak'Mur Overmind, it could be persuaded to convince the other Overminds to withdraw the illithid support of the Valsharess."

"You've seen the proof, have you not? Your surface world attacked, the great Halaster taken hostage... and were you not attacked by the Valsharess's forces? Are none of these things proof of our words?"

Nathyrra studies you closely, and after a moment nods slowly. "Then perhaps the Seer was correct, after all. I suppose we shall see."

"Have you word of anything else?"

The Seer nods slowly. "You have already done much for our cause, <FirstName>. You have my gratitude."
The Seer nods slowly, obviously pleased. "You have done much for us, <FirstName>. The Valsharess will not be able to ignore your actions for much longer."
"I should warn you, <FirstName>... I know something of this mirror. It is a very powerful - but very dangerous - item. What do you intend to do with it?"

The Seer is deep in concentration and cannot speak with you at the moment.
"I can only see the visions Eilistraee chooses to grant me. In her wisdom, she chose to keep me unaware of House Maeviir's impending treachery."
"Perhaps the goddess knew you would be here to save me from my own short-sightedness. Perhaps she wanted me to learn a lesson about who I trust."
"I am just grateful you were here to save me from my own short-sightedness. Perhaps that is why Eilistraee did not give me forewarning of this treachery... she knew you would stop Myrune."
"But we mustn't dwell on House Maeviir's treachery. We have to ready our forces for the next onslaught of the Valsharess."
"Without the Maeviir forces we are at an even greater disadvantage than before, but at least we know those who fight by us now are our true allies."
"Wait a second... who are you? What's going on here?"
"I'm not frightened of you... or anyone, for that matter."
"You awaited my arrival? How did you know I was coming?"
"Did you just call me <CUSTOM500>?"
"Then tell me what I need to know."
"I will do whatever I can to stop her evil."
"I just want to find a way to break this geas on me."
"Help you? I don't even want to be here!"
"I guess you might be right."
"I'll get rid of this geas on me, just you watch."
"I suppose I don't have any choice."
"Why didn't you tell me all of this earlier, Nathyrra?"
"So how does all this involve me?"
"I dreamt about that..."
"I'm sure if she and I spoke, there'd be no reason for such hostility!"
"I will do whatever I can to end such evil. She has reason to fear me."
"It seems the Valsharess and I are on a collision course."
"So what do you propose we do now?"
"That's ridiculous! I mean her no harm in the slightest."
"But the Valsharess can't reach Waterdeep now. Halaster is free."
"How did she bind an archdevil to her service?"
"I am honored by the faith you've put in me, Seer."
"Now that sounds more like it!"
"I don't need your help, tiefling."
"I thought you didn't trust me."
"I'm glad to see you're over your suspicions."
"I'll be going now."
"Why should I help you?"
"I won't fail you, Seer."
"I didn't ask to be a part of this."
"I don't understand... what is it you expect me to do?"
"I have nothing to report right now."
"I should go."
"I have some questions for you."
"Can you tell me anything else about the Valsharess?"
"How can I weaken the Valsharess?"
"Tell me about the Underdark."
"Is there a way back to the surface from here?"
"I don't feel any need to stay here... or do anything else, for that matter."
"You mentioned the Valsharess coming?"
"Tell me more about the duergar?"
"Tell me more about the beholders"
"Tell me more about the illithid."
"Why are you called the Seer?"
"I want to ask you something else."
"Tell me about your visions."
"You had visions of me?"
"And how would you know that?"
<StartCheck>[Bluff]</Start> "I have no idea what you're talking about."
"You mean my dream back at the inn."
"So you are different than most other drow?"
"So you lead these drow, then? Are you a priestess?"
"I don't trust prophets, much."
"There are other drow here?"
"The fact that I worship a different god doesn't worry you?"
"Tell me about Eilistraee."
"This doesn't look like a temple of good."
"She won't mind? What makes you say that?"
"What do you mean by 'serving her cause'?"
"You're all drow. What's to stop me from killing you all now?"
"I'd like to know more about my allies here."
"Do you think you can trust them?"
"That probably makes for some tension."
"I need some healing."
"I have found some golem allies willing to fight with us."
"I killed the Beholder Tyrant. They won't be helping the Valsharess, now."
"I destroyed the Overmind of Zorvak'Mur."
"The mind flayers are no longer allied with the Valsharess."
"I have destroyed the source of the Valsharess' undead hosts."
"That's all for now."
"I have an artifact called the Shattered Mirror."
"I'm sure it will be worth something to someone."
"I don't know. Can you make use of it?"
"I never said I would. I'm keeping it."
"Not for free. But what would you offer for it?"
"Maybe someone else can buy it, then."
"Then take it, anyway. I don't want it."
"Perhaps the mind flayers still want it, then."
"If you can use it, then take it. Maybe it will help."
"I intend to keep it, of course."
"The Zorvak'Mur Overmind is interested in it, actually."
"I need you to give me back the Shattered Mirror."
"I don't have to explain myself to you!"
"I think I might have need of it."
"I'm going to give it to the Zorvak'Mur Overmind."
"I've changed my mind. You keep the mirror."
"I am. Give me the mirror."
"I helped Zesyyr seize control of House Maeviir."
"She paid me."
"Myrune would have betrayed us to the Valsharess."
"We have to get out of here!"
"But I don't want to lead the troops!"
"I will lead your troops to victory, Seer!"
"Let them come! We're ready for them."
"Don't worry, Seer. I won't let you come to any harm."
"Not much of a Seer, are you?"
"Don't blame yourself. We all make mistakes."
"How did they cross the Dark River?"
"Was there ever a doubt? The Valsharess is nothing compared to me!"
"I did what was necessary."
"I could never have done this without your help."
"Be well."
"Cavallas is... odd. He willingly transports followers of the Seer up and down the river free of charge, but otherwise seems unwilling to take an active role in our conflict with the Valsharess."
"He willingly gives out information and shares rumors he has heard during his travels, yet he asks nothing in return. Plus, he shows no fear of anyone or anything."
Valen shrugs. "I honestly don't know what he is, or even why he's here. The Boatman keeps himself hidden beneath his cloak, his face and features completely covered. A little unnerving."
"But I trust Cavallas far more than some of the drow here. I don't get any real sense of threat or danger from him... assuming Cavallas even is a 'him'. You can't tell because of the cloak."
"He'll be in the ports to the east, unless he's ferrying someone along the river. If you ask, he can probably tell you more about the golems and that strange town that just appeared out of nowhere."
The tiefling considers your request for a long time before making his reply. "I don't believe in the Seer's dreams, <FirstName>... though I do believe you want to stop the Valsharess."
"But you already have plenty of companions, <FirstName>. I don't like pooling all our resources in one place. Too easy to suffer a single catastrophic loss if something goes wrong."
Valen nods. "Yes, I think it would be to everyone's advantage if we were to join forces."
"I could join you, but first I think I should tell you about some interesting rumors we should follow up on."
The tiefling gives you a hard stare. "I'm a warrior; a soldier. You would be hard pressed to find one more skilled with the blade then I am. And, like the Seer, I stand against the Valsharess."
"I don't think you're entitled to much more than that, since I barely even know you. The Seer may think you're something special, but I'm reserving judgement until the Valsharess is defeated."
"Untrue," he says softly. "I do not even know you, so I can hardly dislike you. But unlike the Seer, I'm not about to put all my faith in you until you've proved yourself against the Valsharess."
"I've only heard a few rumors and legends concerning some strange islands. Cavallas the Boatman in the ports to the east probably knows more about this than I do."
"By stopping the Valsharess, of course... if you can. But even the Seer seems to realize you can't do this alone, prophecy or not. Fortunately, I may be able to help you out."
"Recently I've heard tales of some strange islands nearby. Based on the legends, there may be something on these islands that could help us against the Valsharess."
"They say there is an island inhabited by powerful golems; these would be particularly useful against the Valsharess and her army."
"I've also heard of a strange settlement that appeared overnight on a previously deserted isle. That sounds like the work of a powerful artifact... one we might be able to make use of ourselves."
"Of course, what I've heard are really just rumors from those who've traveled the river. I'd guess Cavallas the Boatman probably knows more."
"Does that surprise you? There are many rivers and lakes here in the Underdark, and many settlements have ports or docks. The Lith My'athar ports are located just to the east of here."
"You do not have to. Just know that I judge an individual by their actions, not by any supposed destiny laid upon them. If you prove yourself, trust me... I shall be the first to cheer your victory."
Valen shrugs, not taking his intense eyes off of you. "From what I understand, you don't have a choice. Halaster put a geas on you. Either you find a way to stop the Valsharess, or you die."
"Actually, I hope the Seer is right about you. If you prove to be the agent of the Valsharess' destruction, all the better. But I won't bow down to you just because the Seer had a dream."
"Yes, we are. Which is why I'm willing to help you, despite the fact that I know nothing about you. Hopefully you'll prove that the Seer's faith in you is justified."
"I'll be going now."
"You mentioned something about a Boatman earlier."
"Maybe he's some type of ghost or spirit."
"Maybe he's a spy for the Valsharess."
"Where can I find this Boatman?"
"Will you join me?"
"I want to know more about you."
"I get the feeling you don't like me."
"Do you have any information that might help against the Valsharess?"
"You said you could help me against the Valsharess."
"And how am I supposed to prove myself?"
"Tell me about these islands."
"Tell me about this Cavallas."
"Islands? There are islands here?"
"I don't like your attitude, tiefling!"
"What if I don't want to prove myself to you?"
"We're all on the same side here."

Magics of Golem Enhancements

When constructing golems, it is important not to forget the importance of adding enhancements through enchantments. The easiest way to accomplish this is to include spell conduits on your golem creation machine. These conduits can then be filled with the appropriate spells.
It is important to remember that the effects of spells can be altered during the creation process, often producing an unexpected result when they are passed through the spell conduit.
For example: 1. Greater Spell Mantle will improve a golem's resistance to magic. 2. Bigby's Crushing Hand increases a golem's strength. 3. Greater Sanctuary provides more protection against physical attacks. 4. Time Stop grants the golem improved regenaration. 5. Premonition results in improved damage reduction. 6. Mass Haste provides a permanent haste effect. 7. True Seeing provides a permanent True Seeing effect. 8. Chain Lightning causes a lightning bolt to be released whenever the golem is hit by an enemy. 9. Mordenkainen's Disjuntion gives the golem the ability to Dispel Magic each time it hits an opponent.
By placing these spells in the respective conduits, a golem's attributes and abilities can be customized to the creators exact specifications.
