These appear to be notes detailing the Maker's efforts to create sentient golems.
"Despite my best efforts to give birth to a perfect being, all I have managed to create are intelligent golems.
Gifted with self awareness, they are unable to make use of what I have given them. They drift without purpose or direction, they have no concept of accomplishment, art or culture."

These appear to be notes detailing the Maker's efforts to create an entire society of sentient golems.
"I am growing more frustrated with my golem children. They seem incapable of those things that make a living creature truly alive.
Though I have tried to create a society for them, they continue to exist only as isolated individuals. They seem incapable of forming associations and friendships, they only know servant and master.
Perhaps it is my own presence that stunts their growth. Maybe if I leave them to develop their own society, they can overcome the limitations of their own nature."

These appear to be notes detailing the Maker's mounting frustration in his efforts to create a truly sentient creature.
"I am beginning to wonder if a golem can ever be anything more than lifeless materials given animation and form.
Despite all I have given my children - intelligence, self-awareness - they are stunted. They cannot learn or grow, they seem as immutable and fixed as the stone, steel and clay from which they were born."

These appear to be notes detailing the Maker's efforts to create sentient golems.

Strife

The grey-bladed twin of its partner, "Hatred," the witchwood grip of this finely crafted kukri has been stained and darkened by the sweat and blood of countless Shadow Masters over the centuries. There was a time when ownership of the pair inferred the right of leadership over the fabled Guild of Night but, over time, duplicates surfaced, splintering the Guild into countless secret societies, some of which still exist today.
The Guardian Guide

This work appears to detail the Maker's efforts to create a single, perfect golem. Most of the volume describes failed experiments, interspersed with ramblings that demonstrate Alsigard's downward spiral into complete insanity.
However, the final passage reveals an important breakthrough:
"It is all clear to me now. I must construct my greatest success from my previous failures.
First, I must gather 6 pieces from destroyed golems: 2 legs, 2 arms, a torso and the head. Then, I can unlock the golem construction machine by targeting it with the Activator. Once open, I can then place the pieces inside, along with the controlling amulet. This will activate the spell conduits so that I can cast my enchantments on them, giving my creation powers and abilities far beyond any other golem, as described in my previous work 'Magics of Golem Enhancements'.
When the process is complete, I can then retrieve the controlling amulet and use it to summon my perfect being.
The enchantments and powerful arcane spells needed for this delicate process could only be channeled by the most powerful wielders of arcane sorcery. However, I trust that even my apprentices would be able to follow these instructions".

You've met Shaori, the Avariel Queen - though she is now nothing but a reclusive hermit. She mentioned something about pieces of a magical mirror and suggested you should go to the castle if you want to learn more.

You've met an odd little man who claims to be Queen Shaori's fool. He's explained to you that the town is cursed, and that the only way to remove the curse is to recover the missing pieces of a magical mirror. He believes the pieces can be found in the town's library, the temple, the wizard's tower, with the town merchant and with the Queen in her cave.

You've purchased a female slave from the illithid and sent her off to the fighting pits - she fought bravely but died as a gladiator.

Ferron

Ferron, the metallic leader of a group of golem rebels, has asked for your help in retrieving an artifact known as the Power Source so that he can lead the golems away from the halls of the Maker and the tyrannical rule of Aghaaz, the self-proclaimed leader of the golems on the island.

You've given Ferron the Power Source, effectively freeing the golems. As long as they keep the Power Source with them, they can freely travel to any destination they wish. In exchange for your aid, Ferron has promised that his golems will join with you when you move against the Valsharess.

You've learned that the Isle of the Maker was once home to a powerful duergar wizard who retired there to perfect the art of creating golems. Should you wish to investigate this island, Cavallas the Boatman can take you there.

You've discovered a band of duergar on the island, but if you want to learn anything about the Maker or his golems you'll have to explore the remains of his dungeon.
You've encountered a group of sentient golems created by the Maker long ago. They've offered to help you against the Valsharess... if you first help them.
Ferron has promised to send golems to aid the Seer against the Valsharess. No doubt she will be pleased to learn of this new ally.
Aghaaz has promised to send golems to aid the Seer against the Valsharess. No doubt she will be pleased to learn of this new ally.

The small illithid colony of Zorvak'Mur is located to the west of the drow encampment. While killing the Zorvak'Mur Overmind will accomplish nothing, negotiating with it could result in all the Overminds abandoning the Valsharess.

You've freed a group of slaves from the pens of Zorvak'Mur. Under their leader, Argosus, they've launched a bid for freedom. The only downside is that you've likely destroyed any chance you had of convincing the illithid to abandon the Valsharess.

You have found the ancient slab that was supposedly retrieved by the Kobold slave Attiz. The slab might contain useful information about the ruins below.
You have disabled the ancient obelisk that nullified any kind of magic in the tunnels below the Beholder caves. It seems that the core of the obelisk can now be taken.

In exchange, he's offered you the password to get by the Keeper, the guardian protecting the lowest levels of the dungeon.

You've convinced the Maker's assistant to give you the password to get by the Keeper so you can access the lowest levels of the dungeon. In exchange you've promised to bring him the soul gem so he can be free. Whether you actually fulfill that promise remains to be seen...
You've freed the Maker's assistant from his eternal torment and you've managed to learn the password to get by the Keeper, the guardian of the lowest levels of the dungeon.
The Merchant

You've run into a strange merchant who seems intent on getting rid of all his inventory, but only if he can do it without reaping any profits. His only remaining piece of value is a shard of a broken mirror. He will only give it up if he is given something even less valuable in exchange.
According to the Fool, the merchant in the center of town has managed to find one of the pieces of the shattered mirror.

The merchant has given you a magical compass to lead you to his piece of the broken mirror.
When activated, the compass will flash. The closer you get to the mirror shard, the faster it will flash. Using the compass and moving slowly throughout the town you should be able to find where the shard is hidden.
You've found a shard from a broken mirror hidden in a pile of garbage, where it had been stashed by the strange merchant in the town center.
The Temple
According to the Fool, the temple on the western edge of town likely contains one of the pieces of the shattered mirror.

Upon entering the temple you were afflicted with a terrible disease. The only way to rid yourself of this plague is to get the antidote from the temple's resident priest.
He has offered you the antidote if you successfully complete a series of trials by combat. He's also promised to give you a piece of a magical mirror... should you survive.

The priest has told you that Sabal - the leader of the drow who first attacked you upon entering the town - has already completed his challenge and claimed the reward of the broken mirror shard.
However, you are still afflicted with the strange disease, and the priest is the only one who has the antidote. It seems as though you're still going to have to complete his challenge.
You have been given the cure for the strange affliction, although the mirror shard the priest once possessed is now in the hands of Sabal and her drow.
You have been given the cure for the strange affliction and managed to claim the shard of the broken mirror that was in the priest's possession.
The Wizard's Tower
The Fool believes one of the pieces of the shattered mirror is now inside the wizard's tower on the north edge of town.
Petyr, the former archmage who resided inside the tower, has informed you that he found a piece of a magical mirror and gave it to his apprentice, who now dwells within the tower.

On the last level of the tower you've come across the slain body of the wizard's apprentice. It's obvious the drow who attacked you earlier were responsible for his death, and they must have taken anything of value he may have had.
You've claimed the magical mirror shard from the wizard's apprentice.
Undead Army of the Valsharess

Nathyrra has told you that the Valsharess commands a horde of undead. She believe the source of this horde is off to the west of the rebel camp. If you could destroy these undead, it would be a significant blow to the Valsharess.

Nobody is certain where the undead horde of the Valsharess is coming from, though there are rumors of a cult of necromancers hidden in the caverns to the west of the drow rebels. If the cult could be found, the source of all these undead could also be discovered and destroyed.
The Seer was pleased to learn that the Valsharess will no longer be able to call upon the undead hosts in the coming battle.

You've discovered the source of the undead hosts: the cult of Vix'thra had imprisoned an astral deva and were using her blood to animate an army of skeletons and corpses. With the Deva freed from her bonds, the cult can no longer provide undead for the Valsharess... though Vix'thra himself could still be a threat
With Vix'thra's death the cult that was supplying the Valsharess with undead is no more. The Seer will be pleased to learn of this development.
Zorvak'Mur

On your way to the illithid city of Zorvak'Mur, you've encountered a group of duergar slavers. You've learned that the mind flayers of Zorvak'Mur allow non-illithid slavers to enter their city, but you'll need some type of mental protection to keep them from attacking you.
Once inside the city, you need to try and find the Elder Brain. According to the Seer, you may be able to convince it to withdraw the illithid support of the Valsharess.

You've gained access to the illithid city of Zorvak'Mur. As long as you continue to wear the helm that protects you from the mind flayers' telepathic powers, you should be able to convince the illithid that you are nothing but a slaver visiting their city.
You still need to try and find the Elder Brain. According to the Seer, you may be able to convince it to withdraw the illithid support of the Valsharess.

You've promised to give the Zorvak'Mur Overmind a magical mirror. In exchange, it will convince the Elder Concorde - a collection of illithid Elder Brains - to withdraw their support from the Valsharess.

You've freed a group of slaves from the pens of Zorvak'Mur, and they plan to start a rebellion once you've reached the Elder Brain. Should their revolt succeed, you likely won't have any chance of gaining the support of Zorvak'Mur or the illithid in your cause.

You've betrayed the slave rebellion for the sake of the greater good. By denying Argosus and his followers their freedom, you still have a chance to convince the Zorvak'Mur Elder Brain to help you against the Valsharess.
The illithid of Zorvak'Mur have attacked you. The chances of reaching the Elder Brain now are slim, but if you do it might still be possible to negotiate a treaty with it.

You've destroyed the Elder Brain of Zorvak'Mur, crippling the city. However, your actions have done little to harm the Valsharess, as she will simply draw on the illithid from other areas for her army.
You've unleashed a wave of violence in Zorvak'Mur. Any chance you had of gaining the Elder Brain's support is surely lost.

You've given the magical mirror to the Overmind of Zorvak'Mur. In exchange, it has promised to convince the Elder Concorde - a collection of illithid Overminds - to withdraw their support from the Valsharess.
The only drawback is that you have given the illithid a dangerously powerful artifact. No doubt their entire race will become stronger because of it. Despite your success, you can't help but wonder if the cost was too high.

The rugged contraption settles into its new position.
"Hold it right there, boss, this one is going to be good... Deekin says 'Fire away!'"
"Move over, it's Deekin's turn now."
"The other direction, boss! You've got it all backwards!"
"Lower, lower!"
"No, point it higher, boss!"
And so the tale is done.

In the lore of an age that was famed for its heroes as well as its villains, your legend will live on. Scribes will read of your deeds in dusty tomes and marvel that ever there was a time where such an adventurer walked the face of Toril.

Knowing how the tale ends, however, is only part of the story. There is evidence in the old tomes that tell of your fate in the years to come, the fate of your companions and the effect your passing had upon the world.

As for the Sleeping Man, there were few who mourned his passing. The Celestials had long since forgotten him and little love was held for him in Baator. On the far-off plane of Limbo, some githzerai still try to live by his teachings. He is remembered best, perhaps, by the bards who still sing your tale. To them, he is a tragic figure who gambled and lost everything in the name of love...

The ghost of Aribeth de Tylmarande reveled with you amidst the heady spoils of war. She never grew old. She never lost her beauty nor did her feigned passion for you fade. Commanded by her True Name to love you, she played the role faithfully until you were old and gray and triumphant. As you died, she leaned close, biting a chunk of flesh out of your ear. "I shall see you in the Hells, my love," she whispered. She disappeared soon after your death, and legend claims that you did meet once more in the Hells, exactly as she promised. The battle that came then was vicious, its outcome unknown...

The ghost of Aribeth de Tylmarande never grew old and she never lost her beauty. Commanded by her True Name, she did so until you were old and gray and in your dying breath. In that moment between life and death, she leaned close and whispered in your ear, "To the Hells with you, whom I love..."

Nathyrra finally left the Underdark, but she found no freedom on the surface. Forever bound to you by the power of her True Name, she was forced to abandon Eilistraee and the Seer. An absolute slave to your will, she could do nothing but act as you commanded, assassinate whomever crossed your plans and plot a revenge she could never have...

Denied of his true freedom by your command, Valen abandoned his dreams of exploration and instead served your whims slavishly to the end of his days. Though he professed to love you, the claims rang ever more hollow until he was but a shell of a man, a shadow of his former self. He died in his sleep, old and rheumy well before his time, his love of battle's glory long since faded into the monotony of a wasted life...
"Damn my back is sore."
"Stay clear of the Quarry Office. Gru'ul's in a foul mood..."
"Gotta get back to work. Gru'ul's orders..."
"Pike off, I'm on my break."
"That's the sound of the fiends... "
"Hmph? No time. Gru'ul says the Gates are open. We've orders from the generals to gear up for the Blood War. We're opening a new front in the Inner Planes."
1-LINER DEVIL QUARRY WORKER. CAN BE FOUND THROUGHOUT THE CITY BUT CONCENTRATED AROUND THE QUARRY.
"Keep your voice down, <FirstName>. Talk such as that will lead to a lynching."
"Hmph? No time. Gru'ul says the Gates are open. We've orders from the generals to gear up for the Blood War. We're opening a new front in the Inner Planes."
"It is just a devil in his filth, <FirstName>. Unless you intend to do something about it, it's best to leave well enough alone."
"Flames fed by thrice-damned souls, I've heard it told."
"Come on, let's keep moving. He doesn't know anything."
"I must admit, the sensei's faith intrigues me..."
"Hahahahaha! That was funny, boss! Do it to Mephistopheles when we find him, too, okay?"
"Having a change of heart, <FirstName>?"
"Let us rid this place of him and his kind."
"This isn't going anywhere. I say we just kill him."
"You tell him, boss!"
"You tell him, boss!"
"Way to stick up for yourself, <FirstName>..."
"I know you dismantled it, you meddling flame-eared little pantry-smacker!!! The question is, what in the Nine Hells are you going to do about it!!?!?"
"Like I told you last time, rump roast, feed the bloody little pest through! I've got plenty of imps but only one Quarry Grinder 5, understood!?"
"You tell him, boss!"
"No, boss, noooooooooooooooooo! Deekin doesn't want to goooooo!"
"The Seer was wrong about you, <FirstName>. A soul as dark as yours will destroy us all..."
"You are dead to me, betrayer! Speak my name no more..."
"Dark are the days of our acquaintance, then, and may the gods exact their vengeance on your soul..."
"Your days are numbered, <LastName>. Count them well."
"For the sake of my father's blood, do not enslave me amongst my enemies!"
"You wouldn't dare! If I am to be enslaved, let it be in my own home, amongst my own people, not here in these frozen wastes with this blustering devil as my lord!"
"B-b-b-boss? Pick someone other than Deekin, okay?"
"No, <FirstName>, this is unjust! To even consider such a thing is abominable!"
"Go ahead, <FirstName>... I dare you..."
"Do not be tempted, <FirstName>. The righteous can put no trust in devils."
"I don't know if I should commend you for your interest or slit you from nose to gullet, <FirstName>..."
"Noooooo! Don't sell Deekin into eternal slavery, boss! How will he write your epic adventures!?"
"I have a bad feeling about this, <FirstName>, and want no part of it."
"Don't negotiate with scoundrels, <FirstName>! Bash his head in or stand aside and let me do it!"
"What!?"
"Another soul saved from the clutches of Baator! You do Tyr honor, <FirstName>. You do us all honor."

"Hehe, I hear we devils have you to thank for some Gate access, you little skunk-weasel! I've sent word to the generals in the capital and received orders to gear up for a major offensive in the Blood War!"

"But I've got a little spare time on the side right now and a bit of a proposition for you, by way of gratitude. Besides, I've been hearing some tall tales about you lately, you little speck of goat-dust..."
"But I dismantled it!"
"But there's an imp in your grinder!"
"I have known warriors who scarred themselves before every battle. They claimed the wounds gave them the strength to face what was to come."
"Fools and their faith, nothing more."
"It's a long story. There's a temple in the northwest corner of town that I can show you later."
"Be careful, little one. You'll only injure yourself further."
"I have known warriors who scarred themselves before every battle. They claimed the wounds gave them the strength to face what was to come."
"Fools and their faith, nothing more."
"It's a long story. There's a temple in the northwest corner of town that I can show you later."
"That's a serious wound, <FirstName>. Be careful what you promise."
"That doesn't look good, <FirstName>. I'll see what I can do."
"That should teach him..."
"He bears his pain well..."
"I suppose that's one way of handling the matter."
"<FullName>!"
"Eeek!"
"Lost... Our poor leader has joined the Lost..."

"It's only a matter of time..."
The phantom glances up, staring right through you as if you weren't even there.
"It's so... c-c-cold everywhere..."
"The Gates are open... Away with this infernal cold... I'm going home... to haunt... If only I can remember where home is... Maybe I'll just go... and see if I can find it..."

"Would you mind some company?"
"As you wish, <FirstName>."
"Let us leave at once, then. We have many leagues ahead of us."
"There is blood to be spilled, <FirstName>. Let us make this Hell live up to its name."
"Sally forth alone, then. Don't look to me for mercy when I find you gutted on some devil's pike."
"I think I'm beginning to like you."
"You can start by purging the weak from your company, then. Your entourage is too large to travel through the Hells. Too many hangers-on will only slow us down."
"In the name of all that is good, then, do you seek a Paladin of Tyr, once fallen, now redeemed, to fight by your side? I would consider it an honor to serve."
"Then I will stand guard here and clear a space where good might flourish."
"Then let us sally forth and be on our guard. Evil has us outnumbered in this place."
"Then return to me when you have a smaller entourage. If we intend to travel the Hells, we must be lean and efficient, able to share the warmth of a single fire."

"Yes, I learned them once when I first arrived, when I was still struggling to find the meaning of things here. I'm afraid I've forgotten all but the last, however, but that is one I doubt I shall ever forget."

"Engraved in stone at the foot of where he sleeps is the answer to the sensei's Fifth-Fold Mystery: 'She will find you by the Gates of Cania.' The words haunted me somehow and I cannot let go of them, even now."
"Faith is a fool's game, <FirstName>, and I've played it long enough to know. The dreams of the Sleeping Man are just that: dreams... They can be shattered like any other."
But if you must know, I still recall the sensei's Fifth-Fold Mystery. 'What was the answer?' she asks... 'She will find you by the Gates of Cania.' Make of it what you will."
"And I with you. Come, we have much to do."
"I'll forgive you that but I shall not forget it... Let's go."
"Deekin's True Name! What's it you want me to be doing, boss?"
"Nothing? Nothing at all? Well that's a waste of a True Name, if you ask Deekin. How much did you spend on that again, boss? Oh well, we gots an adventure to finish, so hurry up."
"Boss?"
"Yes, boss. Deekin will be all right... Really sad, but all right. Are you planning on dying, boss?"
"Yes, boss. Deekin believe in himself. Anything else?"
"Uh... Boss? Deekin kinda needs that soul. It's the only one he's got, see? Are you sure that's what you be wanting?"
"Oh phew! You had Deekin scared for a second there, boss. Maybe these True Names aren't so much fun after all... Have you gots any other commands for me?"
"Eeek... Okay, boss, here goes nothing... G'bye... So long and thanks for all the fish... Don't let the gate hits you on the way out... AieeeeeEEEEeeee!"
Valen's eyes grow wide as he hears the words. "My True Name," he acknowledges, his eyes filled with a mixture of indignation and awe. "How do you... intend to command me?"
He sneers at you with disgust. "You would force me to love you, my lady? After all we have been through?"
Valen looks at you curiously, as if he didn't quite understand what you said... and then suddenly his eyes go wide. He stiffens, an electrical current running through his body violently.

A moment later, he spasms as a strange, black sheen seemingly lifts from his body and is dispersed. When he opens his eyes there is something... different about him. The otherworldly aura, the rage within his soul... all of it is gone.

"I... I can't believe it!" He looks at himself with incredulity, slowly smiling. "The taint... it's gone! I feel... I feel wonderful! I feel human!!" Laughing joyously, Valen hugs you. "Thank you! Thank you for this wonderful gift!"
Valen's eyes flash a dangerous red. "Take my soul," he growls, "and that will be the end of me. Forever. Are you certain that is what you wish?"
Valen nods, relieved. "Thank you, my <lord/lady>. Please... ask nothing more of me, I beg you."

Before your eyes, Valen begins to shake violently. He screams in pure rage and agony as his vital essence is suddenly stripped away, his physical form fading away to so much dust. Valen's soul is now yours.
He stares at you in confusion. "I am grateful, my lady, but... you would force me to love you? Even though that is not truly love at all?"
He looks away, unwilling to look you in the eyes. "Will there be anything else, my lady?"

Valen stares at you with his intense blue eyes, clenching his jaw. "So be it... my love. Your mastery over me knows no bounds. Should I ever free myself, however... I will kill you. Trust me on that."
Valen's eyes show only relief. "Thank you, <FirstName>. I am grateful. Now... we should go through the gate as soon as possible if we are to rescue your Waterdeep."
He glares at you, his eyes burning a dark red... but he says nothing. Slowly, his gauntleted fists clench and unclench.
Valen struggles to resist your command, but finally gives in. He leans in, kissing you tenderly on the lips with his eyes closed. When you part, tears are streaming down his cheeks.
"I hope this makes you happy, my lady," he spits. He refuses to look you in the eyes.
He stops and gazes into your eyes, his expression suddenly loving. Leaning in he kisses you softly. "I suppose that there is."
"Waterdeep awaits us, my love. The longer we wait here, the more people are hurt by Mephistopheles... he must be stopped."
His smile comes easily to him now. "You have no idea, <FirstName>. It... it is as if a great weight has been lifted from my shoulders."
"Thank you, <FirstName>. I can never repay you for this. Now... we should go through the gate as soon as possible if we are to rescue your Waterdeep."
"My True Name... What... what do you intend to do with me?"
"I... I am relieved. Now hurry, we must go through the gate and return to Toril. If we wait much longer, Mephistopheles will destroy all of Waterdeep."
A look of fear creeps into her dark-veiled eyes. "But if I give you my soul, it will be the death of me. I would be nothing but dust without it... Are you sure of what you ask, <FirstName>?"

"Har, this berk should be good eating."
"Hmph. Wish *I* could grapple around this damn place."
"Bloody mimic's trapped another berk. Let's get 'em!"

As you near the churning lava of this tributary of the River Styx, you can feel the fingers of the Demonic Grappling Hand begin to twitch within your pack. There's a torch bracket on the opposite bank that it seems eager to get to...
"You'll need to use Velox Berries. When it gets this cold, nothing else will ignite the wood."
The passage is blocked by a cascade of ice.
"Gurk? None pass! Ungh! None PASS!!!!"
"You bear the ring, yes? I can smell it... The planetar fooled me once before, long ago... But not again, I say, not again. Mephistopheles would not want that, would he..."

The mimic's smoldering remains fill the air with an acrid stench. The clawed hand it had been using to navigate its lair crawls out, dazed and crablike. Spying the dark sanctuary of your pack, it latches onto your chest, clambers over your shoulder, and scrambles in.

Though you had originally mistaken it as some kind of appendage of the mimic itself, you now realize that it's some sort of fiendish grappling device. Just as you start to feel some pity for the strange creature, you find yourself interrupted...
"Serves the blasted box of wood right, if you ask me. You can't imagine how long it's had me trapped in this place with its infernal magic."

The devil looks at the stump of its wrist where its hand used to be. "Bloody mimics... Well I'm free now and, if I saw what I think I saw, I believe you've got a little something of mine, don't you, berk..."
The crystals that bar your way seem strangely insubstantial to you, as if they exist in only one plane and not the next. Perhaps the Sleeping Man's puzzle ring might be of use here...
"Why you pick 'L', boss? That's not right at all."
"Is there one that starts with 'P', boss? Deekin thinks we should start with 'P'."
"Do you still fashion a blade worthy of a Red Sister?"
"Well they definitely have one in you, Rizolvir. It's good to see you, even though I wish times could be better for us all."
"The weapon you are currently wielding is a throwing weapon. I cannot upgrade those, sorry. However, I can upgrade ranged or melee weapons."
"The weapon you are wielding already has many powerful enchantments. I can not risk to work on such a powerful item, would be too dangerous."
"Any dragons, boss?"
"Definitely big enough to be dragons..."
"And here's where the big mean knight gravely wounded the friendly little dragon before getting eaten... We're getting closer, boss."
"Ooh! Fire-breath! Knights running away in their toasty roasty armor! Hurry up, boss, there's no time to lose!"
"See how scaly their skin was? And their wings? They were dragon babies, boss, fighting over who gets to eat the mean old knight's head!"

"Okay, so over here the dragon tried to make a deal with an evil sorcerer but the evil sorcerer betrayed him and got himself killed. The dragon didn't eat him, though, because sorcerers taste bad. Everybody knows that."

"Oh wow! The mighty dragon slaughtered an entire army and turned everything to rubble and then flew away home! Don't worry, though, boss, he comes back in the sequel. There's always a sequel, right? Are you even listening to me, boss?"
"Eeeek! Don't die, boss!"
"Are you mad?"
"Careful, <FirstName>..."
"Can I see, too, boss?"
"What do you see?"
"Uh-oh. Are you sure you were supposed to do that, boss?"
"Have you got the other one?"
"<FirstName>?"
"Are you all right, <FirstName>? What happened there?"
"Wow! Do that again, boss!"
"It's the sensei's crystal, isn't it... I knew there would be more to it than met the eye! Are you all right?"
"Hello, Mister Rat."
The leader of this fearsome group, a dwarven monk wearing robes that mark him as a member of the Order of the Long Death, watches you with cold, dead eyes as you approach.
"So, <FullName>, it seems the Silent Lord has finally claimed you. It is unfortunate you have ended up here in the Hells, however... since we are planning to take over."
The dwarf nods. "You know my reputation, <FullName>... just as I know yours."
"My name is Grimgnaw. Once I traveled with the Hero of Neverwinter in a battle against Morag and the Old Ones, but that was long ago...
"During my life I was a servant of Death, the Silent Lord. I knew the name and face of all those who delivered souls to my master... those like you, <FullName>."
"In all your adventures, how many have died at your hand? A hundred? A thousand? You have served the Silent Lord well, and you are well known among the Order of the Long Death."
"Enough talk, Grimgnaw. <FullName> is a threat to us here. We must deal with <him/her> as we have dealt with the other spirits that opposed us!"
"Maugrim, you swore your allegiance to me when the power of the Old Ones abandoned you. Do not forget that I am in charge." His underling duly chastised, Grimgnaw turns his attention back to you.
Aribeth gasps in surprise. "I recognize this spirit: Grimgnaw, a dwarf who helped save Neverwinter... and Maugrim! What are you doing here?"
The cleric known as Maugrim gives a cruel laugh. "Aribeth, our paths cross once again. But you will be relieved to know I no longer follow Morag and the Old Ones. Now I have loftier ambitions!"
"With Mephistopheles gone, there is a void that must be filled. This plane of Hell needs someone to rule. Those who swear allegiance to me will be rewarded... those who do not will be destroyed."
"Then you will be destroyed."
The dwarf slowly shakes his head. "No, <FullName>, you are too powerful. Your mere presence here is a threat. If I am to rule, I must destroy all who could one day depose me."
"Only the strongest can rule in the Nine Hells. I am stronger than you, <FullName>, therefore I must rule. And you must be destroyed."
"I know you. You're Grimgnaw, that dwarven monk from Neverwinter!"
"Who are you? How do you know who I am?"
"Time to die, dwarf!" <StartAction>Attack</Start>
"I won't bow before anyone."
"I will swear allegiance to you, Grimgnaw."
"I think I would like to rule this Hell... You will swear allegiance to me!"
"I don't care what you do here, I'm just looking for a way out."

The drow are an evil subrace of elves, living deep underground in the dangerous Underdark.
Donan is a good man, a quiet man. He is also a bald man.
This halfling warrior appears... incomplete. Several good jokes come to mind, but he likely wouldn't appreciate them.

An elderly man with a lopsided grin casually juggles balls of fire at a side table, occasionally earning the scowls of some of the more dour-faced patrons. Two horns protrude from his forehead, one slightly chipped.

The Yawning Portal's cook is know for a temper as fiery as his ovens. (And his outfits)
The drow are an evil subrace of elves, living deep underground in the dangerous Underdark. This one in particular is marked with the insignia of House Maeviir.

This creature is a malevolent elemental formed from the very essence of the hellish rock around you. It is nearly mindless but thrives on its desire to destroy anything living it comes in contact with.

The one-handed fiend, Gargamesh, bellows in anger.

This demon is huge and spider-like, possessing deadly mandibles and a poisonous stinger as well as the customary number of legs. It slavers with an almost mindless viciousness, ready to hunt its fellow fiends as well as whatever other prey crosses its path.

This pale, unearthly creature radiates with an inner energy that seems to penetrate your skin and warm your insides. For all her power, however, this planar being seems to be very much immature, appearing as a teenage human girl.

Mephistopheles is one of the archdevils that rule the layers of Baator. In that plane, his power is supreme... and were he ever loosed upon the Prime Material Plane, the resulting death and chaos would be unimagineable.
Mephistopheles, Small

If you hadn't seen it move with your own eyes, you would believe this creature to be an ordinary treasure chest. Seemingly content with eating gems and rats in its home here, it doesn't seem overly interested in you.
It seems even the hells have their own vermin. These rat-like creatures are slothly and portly, sniffing around the area casually as they search for more gems to gnaw on.
Illithid
This fanged horror bears the scars of its horrendous battle against the Sleeping Man, long ago. It must be one of the Guardians of the Path left behind by Mephistopheles.

This being has been animated from the murky, acidic waters of Cania itself. Akin to an elemental, it has retained the malevolent nature of this hellish plane and exists only to torment any lost souls that are unfortunate to encounter it.

This fiendish wolf is a hunting companion to the frost giants, bred to race after prey and bring it down by force of numbers. It is not native to the prime material plane, existing only in the Outer Planes.
Hell Frost Worg
This is not a wolf at all, truly, but a worg... a fiendish creature filled with hate and rage and existing solely to torment the lost souls of icy Cania.
Alpha Hell Frost Worg

This is not a wolf at all, truly, but a worg... a fiendish creature filled with hate and rage and existing solely to torment the lost souls of Baator. This worg in particular is larger than the rest, being a leader of its pack.
This being has the head of an elderly yet matronly woman... but no body, only butterfly wings. As strange as she looks, she stares at you sternly and likely wouldn't welcome commentary.
Maugrim

A madman who was determined to resurrect the long dead race of lizard folk known as the Old Ones, Maugrim met his end during the siege of Neverwinter. After the battle, the citizens of Neverwinter burned his remains and scattered the ashes to the wind.
This man is covered with coal dust and coughs continuously. When he spots a dead parakeet nearby, he turns pale and begins blubbering with pure terror.
A member of the Waterdeep Militia. The few. The proud. The mighty.
A magic-using member of the Waterdeep Militia. Until recently, all local wizards were required to wear pajamas. This wizard in particular is quite happy that the era of robelessness has ended.
Once a drow of the Underdark, this being is now but a lost spirit, doomed to wander the hells.
A fiendish version of the fire beetle, this creature thrives in the hellish lava pits of Cania and preys on lost souls that come within range.
This monstrosity has been cobbled together from spare bones, animated by an unknown magic. It is completely mindless, akin to a golem, and likely was made to guard something nearby.

This fiendish goblin creature lives amongst the lava pits of Cania, preying on lost souls that pass by. For its relative size and strength, it is a cunning opponent that relies on traps and numbers to take down opponents much stronger than itself.
This small goblin appears unremarkable, though its drooling would indicate that it is less intelligent than others of its kin... if that is possible.

This skeleton is animated by unknown magics and possessed with an evil consciousness. It will hunt down any life it encounters and extinguish it.

"If you are reading this letter, then you have bested one of my Guardians of the Path... Well know this: I have buried the Molikroth Rebels deep in the ice of Cania where they belong. Let them be a symbol of what shall befall those who oppose me! I recommend you turn back while you still have the strength to do so."

The sheet of paper is brittle with age, softened only by the blood of the Guardian who held it. Two sets of handwriting alternate down its length, as if from some magical correspondence. A portion of the end is still legible:
"I have tracked the meddling Planetar to some kind of sepulcher below the ice, m'Lord, but have lost all trace of him from there."
"Find him!"
"But, m'Lord, there is nothing left to find. He is gone."
"Then wait there for him!"
"And if he doesn't return this way?"
"I said wait there! For him or anyone else who may come after..."
"But m'Lord--"
"Your mewling bores me, Guardian. I said wait! If I have different orders for you, I'll send them!"
The ink is old and faded. It seems those orders never came.

"I am about to make my move and lay claim to Toril. Perhaps the Tanar'ri have caught wind of this for I have just received word that they are launching an assault near where I have stationed you. Make your way to the prison and fend them at all costs. The last thing I need is some fool demon getting his paws on my Knower of Names. Serve me well and I may give you lordship over Waterdeep once it is mine..."
It seems that this particular battle of the Blood War sprung up just before he left for your homeworld, Toril.

The origin of this cloak dates back to the days when King Richard Garrison held power in the city-state of Gibbonsfeldt. It was crafted for him by his servant, a demented and twisted man named Pony Tall.
Though Pony was not a gifted man, he managed to sew the cloak in just a few days. It was a misshapen thing, barely resembling a cloak at all, but Pony Tall had done the best he could. Wrapping the tattered garment up, he made way to his lord and master.
Enraged by the gift's insult, King Garrison drew his mighty blade and cut Pony down before all the court, his blood staining the ragged cloak a garish red.
Before tossing the garment out with Pony's stricken corpse, the King placed it around his neck to mock its incompetent maker. The courtiers jeered and laughed at its haphazard manufacture.
Upon placing the cloak about his shoulders, however, the King suddenly felt a little stronger, a little wiser, a little younger. Even the night's cold wind no longer chilled to his aging bones.
It has long been said that a fool's blood spilled in a wise king's court holds a magic unlike any other. As a result, the king's wizards have suggested that the cloak's magic came not from any aspect of its fashioning but instead from the corrupted taint of Pony's blood that paints it red.
Whatever the case, the shroud's power is quite remarkable despite the unseemliness of its appearance. To this day in Gibbonsfeldt, lords and ladies don the most hideous garments they can find to celebrate All Fool's Day and the long, wise reign of Richard Garrison.

A Spirit Devoured

As you left the Reaper's now-familiar domain for the squalid City of Lost Souls that rises around it, you found yourself buffeted by a sudden blast of cold air. A constant, sunless light reflects off the muddied ice and ghostly figures huddle in tattered tents and around flickering fires in an effort to keep the chill at bay. Suddenly a horrific scream cut through the frost-filled air and one of the ghostly figures disappeared in a flash of white. His companions seem more saddened than surprised by his departure. Curious, you resolve to join them around the fire's warmth and question them about what you just witnessed.

As you left the Reaper's now-familiar domain for the squalid City of Lost Souls that rises around it, you found yourself buffeted by a sudden blast of cold air. A constant, sunless light reflects off the muddied ice and ghostly figures huddle in tattered tents and around flickering fires in an effort to keep the chill at bay. Suddenly a horrific scream cut through the frost-filled air and one of the ghostly figures disappeared in a flash of white. According to his companions, who seem more saddened than surprised by their friend's gruesome departure, this is becoming an all-too-common occurrence. Apparently Mephistopheles is devouring the souls of these pale spirits in order to build an army for himself back in your homeworld, Toril.

Arden Swift, patron of the Hellbreath Tavern and itinerant jester currently taveling with the entourage of Githzerai Pilgrims, has placed his beloved Trumpet of Pandemonium as a prize for an upcoming card game. He had intended to use the trumpet to wake the so-called Sleeping Man but had been caught red-handed by the Pilgrims' Sensei before he could sound its blast. If you're interested in acquiring it for yourself, you merely have to place your ante on the table and guess the card he's holding in five questions or less. You're not entirely sure if you can trust him but it might be worth a try.

The archdevil Mephistopheles has played you for a fool. He has commanded your mysterious ally, the Gatekeeper, to bar your return to Waterdeep in your homeworld of Toril, trapping you instead in some hellish world called Cania. The Gatekeeper seems sympathetic to your plight but claims he has no choice but to obey for Mephistopheles has commanded him by his True Name. Such names seem to have a strange power in this place and it seems the only way to break Mephistopheles' prohibition will be learn the Gatekeeper's True Name for yourself.

The Sleeping Man was not as helpful in your quest for the Gatekeeper's True Name as you had hoped. You did learn, however, of an ancient race called the Knowers that populated Cania before it was colonized by the legions of hell. One of them, the Knower of Names, was banished by Mephistopheles to an unknown prison deep in Cania's frozen wastelands. Unable to find the Knower of Names, the Sleeping Man instead sought out her sister, the Knower of Places, with the help of a magical ring that that served as his guide through Cania's wastes. If you can repeat his feat, perhaps she will be able to help you find her sister's hidden prison. The Sleeping Man broke the ring into three parts and hid it in a guarded vault below his chambers. It seems your journey will begin there.

The Sleeping Man's ring that will lead you to the Knower of Places and hopefully to the Gatekeeper's True Name is a strange artifact indeed. When you slip it onto your finger, it is as if you can see into another sort of space, another dimension. Some things are present there that are not present in the real world and some things you would expect to find have disappeared. According to the Sleeping Man, the ring will be most helpful in the out of doors where a line of glowing arrows will apparently chart a safe course for you through Cania's vast wastelands. You feel the stirrings of hope in your chest for the first time since Mephistopheles banished you to this frozen place.

At long last you have learned the True Name of the Gatekeeper: Hecugoth the Abandoned. You say it aloud a few times, rolling it around on your tongue. It has a sad sound to it but you are eager to put it to use. It's your ticket out of here, back to Waterdeep and your homeworld of Toril... or whatever still remains of them after the chaos that Mephistopheles has sown in your absence. The Knower of Names will take you back to the Gates of Cania but you pause to consider whether you have any pressing tasks you wish to accomplish on this plane before you go. Facing Mephistopheles won't be easy and you'd better have made your peace with the world.
Mephistopheles: Ominous Signs

Peering into an ice crystal that thrust itself up from Cania's glacial floor, you saw a vision of Mephistopheles' progress in your homeworld of Toril. It appears that he has discovered the carnage left you behind at the Rebel Camp. As he passed through the rotting carcasses, they rose in his wake, a ghostly army bound to do his bidding...

Peering into an ice crystal that thrust itself up from Cania's glacial floor, you saw a vision of Mephistopheles' progress in your homeworld of Toril. It appears that, together with his newly created army, he is slowly winding his way to the surface, sowing destruction in his wake. Mephistopheles seems to feed off the ruin he is causing. With every moment, he grows stronger...

Peering into an ice crystal that thrust itself up from Cania's glacial floor, you saw a vision of Mephistopheles' progress in your homeworld of Toril. It appears that he has made his way to the surface, emerging in the Yawning Portal. Many of the patrons were incinerated by his deadly gaze, though you don't yet know the fate of Durnan and his family. Even so, time grows short and the city of Waterdeep is in great peril.
Waterdeep lies in near ruins, Mephistopheles' soulless army thick as thieves amidst the rubble. You have been away for far too long and it seems that all your worst fears have come true.

Before you may enter the Temple of the Sleeping Man's Inner Sanctum, you must learn the Five-Fold Mysteries and recite them to Dharvana, the Githzerai Sensei. The Five-Fold Mysteries are as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?
You have learned the answer to one of those five Mysteries.

Dharvana, the Githzerai Sensei, insists that you must learn and recite the Five-Fold Mysteries of the Sleeping Man before she will let you into the temple's Inner Sanctum to see him. She listed the Five-Fold Mysteries as follows: Who is he? From where did he come? Why did he leave? Who did he seek? What was the answer?
You have now learned the answer to two of those five Mysteries.
While visiting the Temple of the Sleeping Man in the city's northwest corner, you've gained access to the Inner Sanctum where the temple's namesake is said to rest.
The Arch-Devil's Guardians

According to the Sleeping Man's dreams, Mephistopheles left five Guardians to block his path. The two weakest were defeated in his quest and the three remaining tricked or avoided. They have grown wiser in the eons since, however, and if you intend to follow in the Sleeping Man's footsteps, you suspect you will have to face each of the three in turn.

Mephistopheles left five Guardians to block the Sleeping Man's path. The two weakest were defeated in ages past and now you have killed the third, a mishapen devil who lay in wait for you just outside the City of Lost Souls.

Mephistopheles left five Guardians to block the Sleeping Man's path. The two weakest were defeated in ages past and a third killed recently by your hands. You have now killed the fourth, a powerful black slaad who must have tracked the Sleeping Man as far as your current location. The Knower of Places must be very close indeed.

Mephistopheles left five Guardians to block the Sleeping Man's path. The two weakest were defeated in ages past and a second and third killed recently by your hands. You have now killed the fifth and final guardian, a wizardly Pit Fiend who stood guard over the prison itself, perhaps there to protect it from the Blood War that raged so close at hand. With all five Guardians dead, the Knower of Names is yours and her secrets too. Now if only you can find some way to free her from the ice.

Gru'ul the fiendish Quarry Boss is no more, though his Quarry Workers continue in their labors, fearful that he might return or that someone even more fearsome might be sent from the capital, Mephistar, to take his place. It is a shame you won't have any further access to the Quarry store.
